{{Infobox civilian attack | title = 2009 Tel Aviv Gay and Lesbian Association centre shooting | image = Nachmani 28 tlv.jpg | caption = The [[The Aguda|Aguda]] building in [[Tel Aviv]], 18 days before the attack took place | location = Tel Aviv branch of [[Israeli Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual and Transgender Association|The Aguda (Israeli GLBT Association)]], Nahmani Street, [[Tel Aviv, Israel]] | coordinates = | date = {{Start date|2009|8|1|df=yes}} | time = 22:40 | timezone = | type = [[Mass shooting]] | fatalities = 2 | injuries = At least 15<ref>[http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid102873.asp Report of incident] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090806093253/http://www.advocate.com/news_detail_ektid102873.asp |date=2009-08-06 }}, advocate.com; accessed 26 March 2015.</ref> | perps = Unknown}}
The '''2009 Tel Aviv gay centre shooting''' resulted in the deaths of two people and injuries to at least fifteen others at the Tel Aviv branch of the [[Israeli Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual and Transgender Association|Israeli LGBT Association]], at the "Bar-Noar" ({{lang-he|ברנוער}}, "Youth Bar"), on Nahmani Street in [[Tel Aviv, Israel]], on 1 August 2009. A 26-year-old man and a 17-year-old girl were killed.<ref name="Hunt still on for TA gay center shooter">{{cite web|url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1248277947570&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull |title=Hunt still on for TA gay center shooter |date=2 August 2009 |publisher=''[[Jerusalem Post]]'' }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref><ref name="Two killed in shooting at Tel Aviv gay center"/> Three deaths were mentioned in earlier reports of the incident but one has since been discounted.<ref name="Police hunt killer of Israel gays">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8180173.stm|title=Police hunt killer of Israel gays|date=2 August 2009|publisher=BBC|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802100413/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/8180173.stm|archivedate=2 August 2009|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Three killed in Tel Aviv shooting">{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/breaking-news/world-news/middle-east/three-killed-in-tel-aviv-shooting-1849435.html|title=Three killed in Tel Aviv shooting|date=2 August 2009|publisher=independent.ie|accessdate=26 March 2015}}</ref>
Most of the injured were minors;<ref name="Two killed in shooting at Tel Aviv gay center"/> six were in serious condition. The city was subject to a "clampdown" after the attacks, and several hundred police launched a manhunt to locate the killer(s).<ref name="Two killed in Tel Aviv gun attack"/><ref name="Police still hunting for Tel Aviv gay center gunman"/><ref name="Gunman attacks Tel Aviv gay centre"/><ref name="Gunman kills 2 at Tel Aviv club for gay youths">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSTRE5701V520090801|title=Gunman kills 2 at Tel Aviv club for gay youths|date=2009-08-02|accessdate=2 August 2009|publisher=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> In June 2013, Hagai Felician was charged over the murder, but the Police retracted its allegations in March 2014, after revealing its key witness fabricated evidence.<ref name="HF"/>
The shooting sparked widespread condemnation, with one lawmaker calling it the worst attack against the gay community in Israel's history. The location of the attack—at the heart of what is seen as Israel's most liberal city— resulted in protests by the gay community.<ref name="Gay group killings prompt Israeli protests"/><ref name="Israeli gays' safe haven turns deadly">{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUSTRE5701V520090802|title=Israeli gays' safe haven turns deadly|date=2 August 2009|accessdate=25 February 2014|publisher=[[Reuters]]}}</ref>
As of 2018, the police had yet to apprehend the shooter.<ref>[https://www.timesofisrael.com/prison-allows-homosexual-conjugal-visit-for-first-time/ Israeli prison allows homosexual conjugal visit for first time], 25 April 2017 Sue Surkes, Times of Israel</ref> ==Shooting== [[File:Tel Aviv gay center shooting memorial.jpg|thumb|Cactus and Succulent plants memorial garden, near the gay center of Tel Aviv, in memory of Liz Troubishi and Nir Katz, murdered in the 2009 Tel Aviv gay centre shooting. The plants were donated from the private garden of Eli Troubishi, Liz's father]] On the evening of August 1 at around 23:00, an unknown person with firearms entered the [[Israeli Gay, Lesbian, Bisexual and Transgender Association|Aguda]] building in [[Tel Aviv]], opened fire on the crowd attending a "Youth Get Together" event, and immediately escaped by foot. Two people were killed, and fifteen were wounded. Police launched a search campaign to find the shooter, and in addition immediately closed most entertainment locations for the gay community that operated during the same time of the shooting for fear of additional shooting.<ref name="Two killed in shooting at Tel Aviv gay center"/><ref name="Two killed in Tel Aviv gun attack"/><ref name="Police still hunting for Tel Aviv gay center gunman"/>
The building was frequented by gay teenagers who engaged in social activities and listened to music.<ref name="Police still hunting for Tel Aviv gay center gunman"/><ref name="Gunman kills two at gay center in Israel"/> The centre was small with one terrace, thus preventing anyone from escaping. Attendees instead hid under a bed and tables as shots were fired.<ref name="Police still hunting for Tel Aviv gay center gunman"/><ref name="Gunman kills two at gay center in Israel"/> Israeli television said the crime scene was a "bloodbath".<ref name="Gunman attacks Tel Aviv gay centre"/> Five of the injured were treated at [[Tel Aviv Sourasky Medical Center]], while five were treated at [[Wolfson Medical Center]] in [[Holon]].<ref name="Police still hunting for Tel Aviv gay center gunman">{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1104624.html|title=Police still hunting for Tel Aviv gay center gunman|date=2 August 2009|accessdate=2 August 2009|publisher=''[[Haaretz]]''}}</ref>
The shooter was masked, dressed in black and used a pistol to carry out the attack.<ref name="Two killed in shooting at Tel Aviv gay center"/><ref name="Two killed in Tel Aviv gun attack"/><ref name="Gunman kills 2 at Tel Aviv club for gay youths"/><ref name="Gunman kills two at gay center in Israel"/><ref name="pistol"/> It was not believed his motive was related to nationalist terrorism.<ref name="Two killed in shooting at Tel Aviv gay center"/> The city's gay community stated the killer had a homophobic motive, while police criticized them for rushing to make declarations about incitement being the cause.<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/police-source-we-have-lead-in-gay-lesbian-center-killings-1.281263]</ref> Police were also investigating leads that the attack may have been due to a personal feud.<ref name="Gunman attacks Tel Aviv gay centre"/><ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1105047.html 2009 Tel Aviv gay centre shooting report], ''Haaretz''; accessed 25 February 2014.</ref>
===Manhunt=== A manhunt was immediately launched in an attempt to locate the gunman.<ref name="Two killed in shooting at Tel Aviv gay center"/> Roadblocks were set up in the city.<ref name="Gunman kills two at gay center in Israel">{{cite web|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/la-fg-israel-shooting2-2009aug02,0,1458101.story|title=Gunman kills two at gay center in Israel|date=2 August 2009|accessdate=2 August 2009|publisher=chicagotribune.com|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090805074147/http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/la-fg-israel-shooting2-2009aug02,0,1458101.story|archive-date=2009-08-05|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Police shut down all other gay clubs and buildings that had homosexual connections near the crime scene immediately after the shooting in case there were further attacks.<ref name="Two killed in shooting at Tel Aviv gay center">{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1104506.html|title=Two killed in shooting at Tel Aviv gay center|date=2 August 2009|accessdate=2 August 2009|publisher=haaretz.com}}</ref><ref name="Two killed in Tel Aviv gun attack"/> Hundreds of police officers were conducting street and door-to-door searches in the city.<ref name="Police still hunting for Tel Aviv gay center gunman"/>
Police soon discarded the possibility that the shooting was a terror attack.<ref name="pistol">{{Citation|last=Boudreaux|first=Richard|title=Israeli gays left feeling vulnerable|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|publication-place=Los Angeles, California|date=3 August 2009|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2009/aug/03/world/fg-israel-attack3| accessdate=19 March 2010}}</ref>
===Reenactment=== Police in Tel Aviv accompanied a teenaged survivor of the attack to the basement to conduct a reenactment on 3 August 2009.<ref name="Police conduct reenactment of Tel Aviv gay attack">{{cite web|url=http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1249418522966&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull |title=Police conduct reenactment of Tel Aviv gay attack |date=5 August 2009 |accessdate=5 August 2009 |publisher=''[[The Jerusalem Post]]'' }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Victims== The dead were named as 26-year-old Nir Katz from [[Givatayim]] and 17-year-old Liz Troubishi from [[Holon]]. One 16-year-old victim spoke of his fear that the shooting would cause an effect of enforced [[Coming out|outing]] as parents find out their children are gay for the first time.<ref name="Police still hunting for Tel Aviv gay center gunman"/>
==Hagai Felician case== Following a police investigation lasting nearly four years, three suspects were arrested. Their arrests were announced on 5 June 2013. A [[gag order]] was placed on the details of the investigation. The three suspects, all residents of [[Pardes Katz]], a neighborhood in [[Bnei Brak]], ranged in ages from 20 to 40. It was later announced that a prominent activist in the Israeli LGBT community had also been detained for questioning.<ref>Eli Senyor. [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4388862,00.html Investigation into 2009 Tel Aviv gay centre shooting], ynetnews.com; accessed 25 February 2014.</ref>
The ''Jerusalem Post'' reported that the shooting was planned by two young men, one of whom believed his teenaged relative had been abused by an activist at the Bar-Noar center. After the shooting, the gunman and his accomplice fled into Tel Aviv. The pistol used by the killer was found by hikers in December 2012 and the suspects were arrested some months later.<ref>Ben Hartman. [http://www.jpost.com/National-News/LGBT-center-shooting-Revenge-for-sexual-abuse-of-minor-316041 "LGBT center shooting: Revenge for sexual abuse of minor"]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, jpost.com, 10 June 2013.</ref>
On 11 June, the gag order was officially lifted. According to police, a few months before the killings, one of the suspects, then 15 years old, came to Barnoar struggling with his sexual identity. There he met with a veteran Barnoar figure, the fourth person to be arrested in the case. Hagai Felician, the teenager's relative, became aware that the teen had been seen a few times at Barnoar, and asked him what he was doing there. The teenager confirmed he had been going there, but that he was raped by the senior figure at the club. Felician allegedly decided to take matters into his own hands, and together with another suspect, Tarlan Hankishayev, and the state's witness, plotted to harm the activist. On the day of the shooting, Felician allegedly came to Barnoar looking for the activist. Unable to find him, Felician “lost it” and shot those present.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/tel-aviv-gay-youth-center-attackers-sought-revenge-over-rape-of-teen-police-reveal.premium-1.529071|title=Tel Aviv gay youth center attackers sought revenge over rape of teen, police reveal|work=Haaretz.com|first=Yaniv|last=Kubovich|date=11 June 2013|accessdate=11 June 2013}}</ref>
On 23 June 2013, charges were dropped against the other two suspects.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/National-News/Murder-charges-dropped-against-two-Bar-Noar-suspects-317473]</ref> On 10 July 2013, Hagai Felician was indicted on two counts of murder.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/10/hagai-felician-indicted-bar-noar_n_3570891.html|title=Hagai Felician Indicted On 2 Counts of Murder in Tel Aviv Gay Center Shooting Case|work=The Huffington Post|first=Stuart|last=Hunter|date=10 July 2013}}</ref>
In February 2014, the prosecution's case against Hagai Felician collapsed after new information was uncovered that suggested that the state witness around whose testimony the case had been built had lied. Subsequently, the witness, who was identified in media reports as "Z" due to his identity being under gag order, was arrested on charges of fabricating evidence. On 26 February, Felician was released, although he was remanded to house arrest until 2 April.<ref>[http://www.jpost.com/National-News/Suspect-in-LGBT-murder-case-Felician-released-to-house-arrest-343638 Bar Noar double murder suspect Hagai Felician released after collapse of state case]</ref> On 9 March 2014, all charges against Felician were dropped.<ref name="HF">[http://www.timesofisrael.com/charges-dropped-against-gay-youth-club-murder-suspect Charges dropped against gay youth club murder suspect], timesofisrael.com; accessed 26 March 2015.</ref>
===Yaakov Felician rape case=== On 24 June 2013, it was cleared for publication that Felician's brother, Yaakov, had been arrested on rape charges, and was suspected of raping a female attorney who had applied to serve as part of Hagai's defense team. Under police interrogation, Yaakov Felician claimed that the attorney had only filed a rape complaint after he did not hire her to serve on his brother's defense team. He was released to house arrest after a [[polygraph]] test determined he was being truthful.<ref>{{cite web|title=Relative of Bar Noar suspect accused of rape |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/relative-of-bar-noar-suspect-accused-of-rape |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HtqCpOU3?url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/relative-of-bar-noar-suspect-accused-of-rape/ |archivedate= 6 July 2013 |deadurl=no |accessdate=1 July 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4398534,00.html</ref><ref>[http://www.jpost.com/National-News/Brother-of-chief-suspect-in-Bar-Noar-case-arrested-for-rape-317557 "Brother of chief suspect in Bar Noar case arrested for rape"], jpost.com; accessed 25 February 2014.</ref>
==Reaction== [[File:Gay memory flag.svg|thumb|200px|right|[[Rainbow flag (LGBT movement)|Pride flag]] with a black "mourning ribbon". This flag was common after the shooting as a mark of mourning and identification with the victims.<ref>Ian Sheinfeld. [http://fr.jpost.com/servlet/Satellite?cid=1249223904109&pagename=JPost/JPArticle/ShowFull "A black day for Israel's gay community"]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, jpost.com, 2 August 2009.</ref><ref>Justin Rudzki. [http://mcv.e-p.net.au/features/city-in-shock-5985.html "City in shock"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090815142920/http://mcv.e-p.net.au/features/city-in-shock-5985.html |date=2009-08-15 }}, mcv.e-p.net.au; 11 August 2009.</ref>]]
===Political reaction=== The murderous event was broadly covered by the Israeli media, and was widely condemned by many public figures. President [[Shimon Peres]] reacted to the murder, stating that: "The horrifying murder that was carried out yesterday in Tel Aviv, against teenagers and young people, is a murder that civilized and enlightened people cannot accept. Murder and hatred are the two most serious crimes in society. The police must exert great efforts in order to catch the despicable murderer, and the entire nation must unite in condemning this abominable act." <ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3755617,00.html Peres: Enlightened nation cannot accept TA shooting], [[Yediot Ahronot]], 2 August 2009.</ref><ref name="Peres: An enlightened people can't accept Tel Aviv gay center murders">{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1104611.html|title=Peres: An enlightened people can't accept Tel Aviv gay center murders|date=2 August 2009|accessdate=2 August 2009|publisher=''[[Haaretz]]''}}</ref> Peres called the culprit a "lowly criminal" and urged the police to apprehend him quickly.<ref name="Peres: An enlightened people can't accept Tel Aviv gay center murders"/>
[[Prime Minister of Israel]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] also condemned the murder at the opening of his Cabinet meeting<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3755571,00.html Netanyahu: Israel a country of tolerance], [[Yediot Ahronot]], 2 August 2009.</ref> He expressed his "shock and dismay", condemning the "shocking murder" and reminding Israeli citizens that "we are a democratic and tolerant country and we must respect every person as he is".<ref name="Two killed in Tel Aviv gun attack">{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2009/0802/israel.html|title=Two killed in Tel Aviv gun attack|date=2 August 2009|accessdate=2 August 2009|publisher=[[Raidió Teilifís Éireann|RTÉ]]}}</ref><ref name="Israeli gays' safe haven turns deadly"/><ref name="Peres: An enlightened people can't accept Tel Aviv gay center murders"/>
[[Nitzan Horowitz]], the only openly gay member of the [[Knesset]] at the time, condemned it as "the worst attack ever against the gay community in Israel [...] a blind attack against innocent youths.<ref name="Gunman attacks Tel Aviv gay centre"/><ref name="Israeli gays' safe haven turns deadly"/><ref name="Gunman kills two at gay center in Israel"/><ref name="Peres: An enlightened people can't accept Tel Aviv gay center murders"/>
The [[Shas]] party said they were "shocked and bereaved, and denounce without reservation the murderous incident". Public Security Minister [[Yitzhak Aharonovich]], head of Israel's police force, called it "a serious and grave incident". Aharonovitch spoke of going to the crime scene, saying "it was a difficult sight".<ref name="Peres: An enlightened people can't accept Tel Aviv gay center murders"/>
Opposition leader [[Tzipi Livni]] called it a "grave incident", saying "even if all the details surrounding the event are not yet clear, the hatred exists and must be dealt with".<ref name="Peres: An enlightened people can't accept Tel Aviv gay center murders"/> She said it should "awaken society to rid itself of prejudice" and "shake up society, and all the circles inherent in it, including the political establishment and the education system, and on this day deliver an unequivocal message against intolerance, incitement and violence, and to act against any manifestation of these".<ref name="Peres: An enlightened people can't accept Tel Aviv gay center murders"/>
The Mayor of Tel Aviv, [[Ron Huldai]], said his city would still welcome members of the gay and lesbian community, saying they would fight for their rights to live.<ref name="Two killed in Tel Aviv gun attack"/><ref name="Israeli gays' safe haven turns deadly"/> Tel Aviv's Head of Police, Shachar Ayalon, did not say the shooting was a hate crime.<ref name="Two killed in Tel Aviv gun attack"/>
On 8 August, days after the event, Peres came to the crime scene at Bar-Noar to show support for the community and the deadly attack on it.<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3757975,00.html "Netanyahu visits Tel Aviv gay center"] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5j5LVuvg9?url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3757975,00.html |date=2009-08-17 }}, ''[[Yediot Ahronot]]'', 8 August 2009; accessed 6 August 2009.</ref><ref>[https://www.webcitation.org/5j5LVuvg9?url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3757975,00.html Archived records]; 16 August 2009.</ref>
===Protest rally=== A protest rally was held in Tel Aviv following the shooting, including lit candles.<ref name="Gunman attacks Tel Aviv gay centre">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/08/200981202254903397.html|title=Gunman attacks Tel Aviv gay centre|date=2 August 2009|accessdate=2 August 2009|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090802101338/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2009/08/200981202254903397.html| archivedate=2 August 2009|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref name="Gay group killings prompt Israeli protests">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/08/02/2643448.htm?section=world|title=Gay group killings prompt Israeli protests|date=2 August 2009|accessdate=2 August 2009|publisher=American Broadcasting Company}}</ref><ref name="Gunman kills two at gay center in Israel"/>
A few hours after the event, a demonstration of a few hundred people took place on [[Rothschild Boulevard]] in Tel Aviv, and the protesters marched towards [[Allenby Street]], and [[King George Street (Tel Aviv)|King George Street]] until they reached [[The Municipal Center for the Gay Community]], in [[Meir Park, Tel Aviv|Meir Park]], and on the way chanted ''"Inciting homophobes, children's blood is on your hands."'' {{cn|date=February 2014}} The next day, at 17:00 pm, an additional demonstration took place on Rothschild Boulevard, and in addition a protest watch was held in [[Mount Carmel]]'s range, in [[Haifa]] City in the north,<ref name="Police conduct reenactment of Tel Aviv gay attack"/> a known entertainment place as well, and also in [[Zion Square]] in [[Jerusalem]] and in the government complex in [[Beer-Sheba]].{{cn|date=July 2018}}
===International reaction=== On 3 August 2009, more than 150 Jewish and LGBT people held a [[candlelight vigil]] in the [[Dupont Circle, Washington, D.C.|Dupont Circle]] neighborhood of [[Washington, D.C.]], the capital of the United States. Rabbis and Jewish community leaders representing [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox]], [[Conservative Judaism|Conservative]], and [[Reform Judaism|Reform]] congregations were among those in attendance. On 3 August 2009, more than 100 people held a memorial service<ref>[http://sfjcf.wordpress.com/2009/08/03/lgbt-shooting-vigil San Francisco memorial for victims of the 2009 Tel Aviv gay centre shooting"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110308080345/http://sfjcf.wordpress.com/2009/08/03/lgbt-shooting-vigil/ |date=2011-03-08 }}, sfjcf.wordpress.com; accessed 25 February 2014.</ref> at the San Francisco LGBT Center organized by the LGBT Alliance of the Jewish Community Federation of San Francisco, the Peninsula, Marin & Sonoma Counties and the Jewish Community Federation of the Greater East Bay. Rabbi Camille Shira Angel from Congregation Sha'ar Zahav, Supervisor Bevan Dufty, among others, spoke in condemnation of the violence.{{cn|date=July 2018}}
On 31 August 2009, a cousin of Nir Katz — together with the Vancouver Hillel Foundation — organized a candlelight vigil in honour of the victims at the Vancouver Art Gallery in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada. The evening's service drew about 100 people and served as a rally against hate crime. This vigil also served to mark ''Shloshim'', which in the Jewish tradition is a service to mark the end of the 30-day mourning period following the death.<ref>{{cite web|title=Welcome to the Jewish Independent Online |url=http://www.jewishindependent.ca/Archives/Sept09/archives09Sept04-02.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jq7jLpLh?url=http://www.jewishindependent.ca/Archives/Sept09/archives09Sept04-02.html |archivedate=16 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=14 September 2009 |df= }}</ref> A video recording of this vigil can be found on youtube.com under the title "Vancouver Vigil — In Memory of Nir Katz (1983-2009) Parts 1 through 5".<ref>{{cite web |title=YouTube — Vancouver Vigil — In Memory of Nir Katz (1983-2009), part 1/5 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LI8QWgIiiKU |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jq7jgcdK?url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LI8QWgIiiKU |archivedate=16 September 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=14 September 2009 |df= }}</ref> A separate vigil was held in [[Toronto]]. A rally to condemn the shootings was held in [[Berlin]].<ref>[http://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-3757305,00.html "Demonstration in Berlin following the Shooting in Tel-Aviv gay center"], ynet.co.il, 8 May 2009.</ref>
===Solidarity rally=== [[File:Atzret 8.8.2009.JPG|thumb|right|[[Yahrzeit candle]]s and signs entitled "[[Ten Commandments|You shall not murder]]" at the rally at [[Rabin Square]] on 8 August 2009.]] A week after the murder, on 8 August, a solidarity rally was held in [[Rabin Square]] in [[Tel Aviv]]. Twenty thousand demonstrators or more gathered to show solidarity with Israel's gay community, including the victims shot at the center.<ref name="HAAR">[http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1106147.html 20,000 gather in Rabin Square over gay center shooting], [[Haaretz]], Noah Kosharek</ref> President [[Shimon Peres]] addressed the crowd, saying the shots fired at the gay and lesbian community "hurt all of us — as people, as Jews, as Israelis."<ref>[https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE57722120090808 Huge crowd shows solidarity with Tel Aviv gays], af.reuters.com, 8 August 2009.</ref> Also attending the rally were Minister of Education [[Gideon Sa'ar]], Minister of Culture [[Limor Livnat]], Minister of Welfare & Social Services [[Isaac Herzog]], various Knesset members, and Israeli singers such as [[Rita (Israeli singer)|Rita]], [[Dana International]], [[Ninet Tayeb]], [[Keren Peles]], [[Ivri Lider]] and [[Margalit Tzan'ani]]. In Jerusalem, members of the LGBT community lit candles at [[Zion Square]] in a tribute to the victims at a vigil.<ref name="HAAR"/>

module3 = | module4 = | module5 = | module6 = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Assaf Abu Rahhal''' ({{lang-ar|عساف أبو رحال}}; 18 December 1955 – 3 August 2010) was a veteran [[Lebanon|Lebanese]] [[journalist]] who was killed by the [[Israeli Defense Forces]] during the [[2010 Israel–Lebanon border clash]].,<ref name=dailystar>{{cite news|last=Zaatari|first=Mohammed|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=1&categ_id=2&article_id=117831|title=Journalist Abu Rahhal slain while reporting on clashes|publisher=The Daily Star|date=10 August 2010|accessdate=8 September 2012}}</ref><ref name=nl>{{cite news|url=http://www.nowlebanon.com/NewsArchiveDetails.aspx?ID=191293|title=Al-Akhbar’s journalist killed in Tuesday’s clashes|publisher=Now Lebanon|date=3 August 2010|accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref><ref name=cpj>{{cite web|url=http://cpj.org/killed/2010/assaf-abu-rahal.php|title=Assaf Abu Rahal |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|date=3 August 2010|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref> in which an Israeli reserve lieutenant colonel was killed and a captain was shot and injured by Lebanese sniper fire.
According to [[Reporters Without Borders]], Abu Rahhal was the first Lebanese journalist killed since 2006 when Lebanese and Israeli forces clashed.<ref name=rsf>{{cite web|url=http://en.rsf.org/liban-lebanese-journalist-killed-when-03-08-2010,38093.html|title=Lebanese journalist killed when Israeli tank opens fire|publisher=Reporters Without Borders|date=3 August 2010|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref> He was one of five people to die in the incident, which received international attention and scrutiny, but he was the only journalist killed.<ref name=bbc>{{cite news|first=Wyre| last=Davies|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-10851692|title=Israel-Lebanon border clash kills five people|publisher=BBC News|date=3 August 2010|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref><ref name=independent>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/commentators/fisk/robert-fisk-israellebanon-tensions-flare-after-skirmish-leaves-four-dead-2042501.html|first=Robert|last=Fisk|title=Israel-Lebanon tensions flare after skirmish leaves four dead|publisher=The Independent (UK)|date=4 August 2010|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref>
==Personal== [[File:Adaysseh-hezb.JPG|thumb|400px|The Lebanese border-area village of Adaisseh, as seen from Misgav Am, Israel.]] Assaf Abu Rahhal was a native of [[Kfeir]], [[Hasbaya District]], Lebanon. He was married and a father of three. He died in [[Adaisseh]], Lebanon, while reporting for his newspaper, as a result of Israeli military fire. Final services were held at Saint George Roman Orthodox Church in Kfeir for the deceased.<ref name=dailystar /> The village of Adaisseh commemorated Abu Rahhal's death on the second anniversary of his death.<ref name=aa2012>{{cite news|title=Lebanon’s Southern Border: Life is Not a Bed of Roses|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/content/lebanons-southern-border-life-not-bed-roses|publisher=Al-Akhbar|first=Amal|last=Khalil|date=6 June 2012|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref>
==Career== Abu Rahhal worked for the [[Al Akhbar (Lebanon)|''Al Akhbar'']] daily newspaper for four years where he was covering southern Lebanon.<ref name=cpj /> Before that he was a journalist with ''[[Al-Mustaqbal (newspaper)|Al-Mustaqbal]]'', an Arabic daily newspaper, and he sometimes wrote for ''Shu’un Janoubiah'' magazine.<ref name=dailystar />
==Death in border incident== {{Location map+ | Lebanon | relief = 1 | position = left | width = 200 | caption = Mentioned locations within Lebanon relative to Beirut. | places = {{Location map~ | Lebanon | label = Beirut |lat_deg = 33 | lat_min = 53| lat_sec= 19| lat_dir = N | lon_deg = 35 | lon_min = 29 |lon_sec= 43 | lon_dir = E}} {{Location map~ | Lebanon | label = Adaisseh | lat_deg = 33.15 | lon_deg = 35.32 }} {{Location map~ | Lebanon | label = Kfeir | lat_deg = 33.26 | lon_deg = 35.44 }} }} The dispute began around noon on 3 August 2010 when Israeli forces began to dig up a tree at the border between [[Misgav Am]], [[Israel]] and Adaisseh, Lebanon. The [[United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon]] had given the Israelis permission to do the maintenance. The Lebanese claimed the Israelis had crossed border in conducting this work. The Israelis disputed this claim, and the UN Peacekeeping force also dismissed the border crossing claim.<ref name=bbc /> Lebanese sniper fire ensued. Both sides agree that the Lebanese issued a verbal warning prior to the shooting and the Israelis stood their ground and claimed they were on Israeli territory.<ref name=nytimes>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/08/04/world/middleeast/04mideast.html?_r=2&hpw|title=Lethal Clash at Israeli-Lebanon Border|last=Kershner|first=Isabel|last2=Bakri|first2=Nada|publisher=New York Times|date=3 August 2010|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref> After an Israeli reserve lieutenant colonel was killed and a captain was shot and injured, the Israelis responded to the sniper fire from the Lebanese side of the border.<ref name=jp>{{cite news|last=Katz|first=Yaakov|url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Article.aspx?id=183525|title=IDF commander killed on Lebanon border|publisher=Jerusalem Post|date=3 August 2010|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref> UN forces intervened to bring a halt to the armed conflict. Reporters Without Borders said the Israelis wanted to install a surveillance camera on the site of the tree.<ref name=rsf /> This was the first armed incident since [[2006 Lebanon War]] and a violation of the [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1701|UN Resolution 1701]] to prevent further conflict.<ref name=cnn>{{cite news|author=the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/meast/08/03/lebanon.israel.hostilities/index.html?hpt=T2#fbid=jPcEx8LKgWv |title=Tensions rise as deadly border clash erupts between Israel, Lebanon|publisher=CNN|date=2010-08-03|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref>
In all, one Israeli officer, three Lebanese soldiers and Lebanese journalist Abu Rahhal were killed in the incident. In addition one Israeli officer was wounded and on the Lebanese side four soldiers were wounded and Lebanese TV reporter Shoaib.<ref name=bbc /><ref name=telegraph>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/7925053/Five-killed-in-clashes-on-Lebanons-border-with-Israel.html|title=Five killed in clashes on Lebanon's border with Israel|first=Adrian|last=Bloomfield|publisher=The Telegraph (UK)|date=3 August 2010|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref>
==Reactions== The killing of Abu Rahhal was condemned by [[Irina Bokova]], who is the director-general of [[UNESCO]]: "I am deeply concerned about the circumstances in which Assaf Abu Rahhal was killed and his colleague Ali Shoaib injured ... I would further underline that freedom of expression, a fundamental human right, implies the possibility of exercising this right in safety. Armed forces are obligated to respect it."<ref name=unesco>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=35541&Cr=leban&Cr1=|title=UNESCO chief deplores killing of Lebanese journalist |publisher=UN News Centre|date=5 August 2010|accessdate=2012-09-08}}</ref>
Lebanon’s Syndicate of Photographers and the Maharat Foundation condemned the attack.<ref name=dailystar /> The French-based Reporters Without Borders said Abu Rahhal's death was due to an "Israeli military blunder."<ref name=rsf />
Al-Akhbar editor Omar Nashabe said, "It is totally unacceptable that a civilian, a dedicated journalist, husband and father, be targeted and killed while the international community and UN troops [in southern Lebanon] stand by idly."<ref name=nl /> News reports contradict the charge that Abu Rahhal was targeted.<ref name=telegraph />
==Other journalists killed on the border== According to the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists, the following Lebanese and Israeli journalists have died along the Israeli-Lebanese border in addition to Assaf Abu Rahhal: [[Ahmed Haidar]] of Al-Manar died in 1993;<ref name=cphhaidar>{{cite web|url=http://cpj.org/killed/1993/ahmed-haidar.php |title=Ahmed Haidar|publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|date=26 July 1993|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref> [[Ilan Roeh]] of [[Israeli radio]] died in 1999.<ref name=cpjroeh>{{cite web|url=http://cpj.org/killed/1999/ilan-roeh.php |title=Ilan Roeh|publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|date=28 February 1999|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref> [[Layal Najib]], a freelance photographer, died in the border dispute in 2006.<ref name=cpjnajib>{{cite web|url=http://cpj.org/killed/2006/layal-najib.php|title=Layal Najib |publisher=Committee to Protect Journalists|date=23 July 2006|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref> She was the last journalist to have been killed before Abu Rahhal.
The shooting of Lebanese TV journalist [[Ali Shabaan]] by Syrian forces on the Lebanese-Syrian border 9 April 2012 stirred up memories of Abu Rahhal at ''Al-Akhbar''.<ref name=alishabaan>{{cite news|url=http://english.al-akhbar.com/blogs/angry-corner/ali-shabaan-and-assaf-abu-rahhal|title=Ali Shabaan and Assaf Abu Rahhal|first=As'ad|last=Abu Khalil|publisher=Al-Akhbar|date=13 April 2012|accessdate=2012-09-09}}</ref> Shabaan was the next journalist after Abu Rahhal to have been killed near the Lebanese border.
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * See portrait here: [http://www.dailystar.com.lb/article.asp?edition_id=1&categ_id=2&article_id=117831] * Image of body here: [http://honestreporting.com/special-alert-media-collusion-in-lebanon-ambush/]
{{authority control}}

{{context|date=August 2012}} The '''belief–desire–intention''' ('''BDI''') model of human practical reasoning was developed by [[Michael Bratman]] as a way of explaining future-directed intention.
BDI is fundamentally reliant on [[folk psychology]] (the 'theory theory'), which is the notion that our mental models of the world are theories. It was used as a basis for developing the [[belief–desire–intention software model]].
==Applications==
BDI was part of the inspiration behind the [[Belief–desire–intention software model|BDI software architecture]], which Bratman was also involved in developing. Here, the notion of intention was seen as a way of limiting time spent on deliberating about what to do, by eliminating choices inconsistent with current intentions.
BDI has also aroused some interest in psychology. BDI formed the basis for a computational model of childlike reasoning [https://web.archive.org/web/20070629002644/http://cognition.iig.uni-freiburg.de/csq/pdf-files/Wahl_Spada.pdf CRIBB]. It has been proposed that autistic children do not recognise other people as folk-psychological agents (i.e., agents with their own beliefs, etc.). BDI has been used to develop a [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/iel5/7906/21803/01011803.pdf rehabilitation strategy] to teach autistic children to reason about other people.
== References ==

{{italic title}} '''''Biotech Sweden''''' was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|tabloid]] magazine about and for the Scandinavian life science and biotech industry.
==History and profile== ''Biotech Sweden'' was first published on 9 April 2002 by IDG Sweden, a subsidiary of [[International Data Group|IDG]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Jan Sandred|title=Biotech Sweden – A Business Model Case Study in Innovation Journalism|url=http://innovationjournalism.org/archive/INJO-1-3_split/INJO-1-3_sandred.pdf|work=Innovation Journalism|accessdate=6 May 2015|format=Conference Paper|date=April 2004}}</ref> It was sister publication of ''Bio-IT World''.<ref name=ada/> At its initial phase ''Biotech Sweden'' was published seven times a year.<ref name=ada>{{cite news|title=IDG to publish 'Biotech' magazine in Sweden|url=http://adage.com/article/btob/idg-publish-biotech-magazine-sweden/253684/|accessdate=6 May 2015|work=Ad Age|date=14 February 2002}}</ref> Then it began to be published 11 times per year. The readers were mainly people working in the [[biotechnology]] [[Medical technology|medtech]] and [[Pharmaceutical industry|pharma]] industry of the [[Nordic countries]]. It also carried the largest life science web news service of the Nordic countries, www.lifesciencesweden.se, with four newsletter distributed three times a week, subscription free-of-charge. On the website the magazine provided daily news in Swedish and a weekly news-letter covering life science news of the Nordic countries, plus also access to The Scandinavian Life Science Industry Guide, a database of all life science, medtech and labtech companies of Scandinavia. ''Life Science Sweden'' is also official media partner of Sweden Bio.
The [[editor-in-chief]]s included Ingrid Heath, Jörgen Lindqvist, Ingrid Helander and Loth Hammar.
In 2012, the magazine changed its name to ''Life Science Sweden'' and in 2013 it was sold to Mentor Communications AB.

'''Christian Boussus''' (5 March 1908 – August 2003) was a left-handed French [[tennis]] player who found success in the 1920s and 1930s.
==Tennis career== He started playing amateur tennis in the late 1920s by entering one of his first tournaments at the age of 17 in the 1926 edition of The French Covered Courts tournament in doubles, which he won by teaming up with French veteran [[René Lacoste]].<ref name="straitstimes2">{{cite journal | editor = | url = http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19320320.2.23 | author = Nigel Sharpe | authorlink = | issue = 14 | journal = [[The Straits Times]] | date = 20 March 1932 | title = Boussus – France's great left-hander | publisher = Straits Times Press | location = Singapore, [[Straits Settlements]] | page = 3 | accessdate = 17 September 2012 }}</ref> He was the runner-up at the [[Los Angeles Open (tennis)|Pacific South-west Championship]] in 1928<ref name="eveningpost">{{cite journal | date = 8 October 1928 | title = International Tennis | editor = | journal = [[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|Evening Post]] | page = 5 | location = [[Wellington]], New Zealand | publisher = Blundell Bros Limited | volume = 106 | issue = 75 | accessdate = 17 September 2012 | url = http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19281008.2.22&srpos=22&e=--1927---1944--10--21----0boussus-- }}</ref>(lost to fellow Frenchman [[Henri Cochet]]) although he won the mixed title trophy alongside American [[Anne Harper]].<ref name="eveningpost3">{{cite journal | date = 9 October 1928 | title = Frenchmen victors | editor = | journal = [[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|Evening Post]] | page = 9 | location = [[Wellington]], New Zealand | publisher = Blundell Bros Limited | volume = 106 | issue = 75 | accessdate = 17 September 2012 | url = http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19281009.2.58&srpos=147&e=--1927---1944--10--141----0boussus-- }}</ref> The same year he won his first outdoor doubles title in [[Düsseldorf]] pairing Davis Cup teammate [[Jean Borotra]].<ref name="aucklandstar2">{{cite journal | date = 24 July 1928 | title = International tennis | editor = | journal = [[Auckland Star]] | page = 7 | location = [[Auckland]], New Zealand | publisher = | volume = 59 | issue = 173 | accessdate = 17 September 2012 | url = http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=AS19280724.2.66&srpos=2&e=01-01-1928-31-12-1928--10--1----0boussus+dusseldorf-- }}</ref> He won his first singles championships in 1929.<ref name="miroir">{{cite journal | date = 13 August 1929 | title = Boussus remporte son premier championnat | editor = Paul Dupuy | journal = [[:fr:Miroir des sports|Miroir des sports]] |trans-title=Boussus gains his first championship title | location = Paris, France | publisher = Le Petit Parisien Press Group | editor-link = Paul Dupuy | volume = | issn = | accessdate = 17 September 2012 | url = http://www.muhlemann.ch/miroir_sports_a_1932.htm }}</ref> He was on the victorious French team at the [[Davis Cup]] four times, in 1929, 1930, 1931, and 1932, although he never played.<ref name="figaro" /><ref name="cyprustennis">{{cite web | url = http://www.cyprustennis.com/main/data/DC_12592_original.pdf | title = 2010 Davis Cup Media Guide | format = PDF | publisher = Cyprus Tennis Association | work = cyprustennis.com | year = 2010 | author = ITF | authorlink = International Tennis Federation | accessdate = 2012-09-15 | location = [[Nicosia]], [[Cyprus]] }}</ref> The members of the team became known as the "[[The Four Musketeers (tennis)|Four Musketeers]]" and Boussus was the "Fifth Musketeer".<ref name="bagnerestennis">{{cite web | url = http://future-bagneres.a3w.fr/Main.aspx?numStructure=82681&numElement=116638&numRubrique=528611&transfert=1 | title = Participations célèbres |trans-title=Famous participants | publisher = Club de Bagnères-de-Bigorre | work = future-bagneres.a3w.fr | date = | language = French | authorlink = | accessdate = 2012-09-15 | location = [[Bagnères-de-Bigorre]], France }}</ref> He finally got his chance to play at the Davis cup in 1934, when the Four Musketeers had retired. During [[World War II]] in 1941 in [[Vichy France]] he won the [[Tournoi de France (tennis)|unofficial French Open]] doubles title partnering [[Bernard Destremau]], a feat that is unrecognized by the ITF.<ref name="racingclub">{{cite web | url = http://www.racingclubdefrance.net/racing/tennis/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1&Itemid=2 | date = | title = Presentation | format = | publisher = Racing Club de France | work = racingclubdefrance.net | author = | authorlink = | accessdate = 2012-09-17 | location = Paris, France }}</ref> The same year he starred in a movie called "L'Appel du stade".<ref name="movie">{{cite web | url = http://www.parisenimages.fr/en/popup-photo.html?photo=7684-11 | title = L'Appel du stade |trans-title=| publisher = parisenimages.fr | work = | date = September 1941 | language = | author = Roger-Viollet | accessdate = 2012-09-17 | location = Paris, France }}</ref> After the war he became the captain of the [[French Davis Cup Team]] between 1949–1952<ref name="francetennis">{{cite web | url = http://ww2.fft.fr/archives/web2001/cd_australie_2001/stats_france.html | year = 2001 | title = Finale Coupe Davis Melbourne 2001 | publisher = [[Fédération Française de Tennis]] | work = fft.fr | author = | authorlink = | accessdate = 2012-09-15 | location = Paris, France }}</ref> and vice-captain from 1953.<ref name="canberratimes">{{cite journal| date=21 May 1953 | title=Rosewall wins in Paris | editor=Arthur Shakespeare | journal=[[The Canberra Times]]| page=6 | location=[[Canberra]], Australia | publisher=Federal Capital Press of Australia| editor-link=Arthur Shakespeare | volume=27 | issue=8,028 | accessdate= | url= http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article2882431}}</ref> In the very first year of his leadership France reached the final of the [[1949 Davis Cup]] for the first time in 15 years. In club level team competitions he represented Racing Club de France of Paris.<ref name="racingclub2">{{cite web | url = http://www.la84foundation.org/OlympicInformationCenter/OlympicReview/1988/ore254/ORE254m.pdf | date = | title = Jean Borotra | format = PDF | publisher = LA84 Foundation | work = The Witnesses | author = Marie-Hélène Roukhadzé | page = 684 | accessdate = 2012-09-17 | location = Los Angeles, United States }}</ref>
[[File:Christian Boussus Vivian McGrath.jpg|thumb|Christian Boussus (left) and [[Vivian McGrath]] (center) enter the center court of the [[White City Stadium]] in Sydney, Australia in November 1934]] Boussus was defeated in the finals of the 1931 [[French Open (Tennis)|French Championships]] by [[Jean Borotra]]. In 1932, he and [[Marcel Bernard]] were defeated in the doubles finals of the French Championships by [[Henri Cochet]] and [[Jacques Brugnon]].<ref name="eveningpost2">{{cite journal | date = 30 May 1932 | title = Tennis in France | editor = | journal = [[The Evening Post (New Zealand)|Evening Post]] | page = 10 | location = [[Wellington]], New Zealand | publisher = Blundell Bros Limited | volume = 113 | issue = 126 | accessdate = 17 September 2012 | url = http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19320530.2.88&srpos=78&e=--1927---1944--10--71----0boussus-- }}</ref> He played twice the Australian Championships, in 1928 and 1935, and won the mixed doubles that year, his only Grand Slam title. He competed in the French Championships nineteen times between 1927 and 1953, which is the third most appearances in history right after [[Fabrice Santoro]] (20) and [[Francois Jauffret]] (20).<ref name="équipe">{{cite journal | date = 27 May 2009 | title = Santoro, record égalé | editor = François Morinière | journal = [[L'Équipe]] |trans-title=Santoro, ties record | location = Paris, France | publisher = Éditions Philippe Amaury | editor-link = | issue = 20046 | page = 12 | volume = 64 | issn = 0153-1069 | accessdate = 17 September 2012 | url = http://www.docstoc.com/docs/6525595/LEquipe-du-27-mai-2009 }}</ref> Boussus twice won the [[German Open Tennis Championships|German Championships]] in [[Hamburg]] (1930, 1931) and the [[British Hard Court Championships]] on one occasion (1931).<ref>{{cite news|title=Deutsche Tennismeisterschaften|url=http://www.theeuropeanlibrary.org/tel4/newspapers/issue/3000117634119?hp=1&count=10&page=13|work=[[Hamburger Nachrichten]]|date=14 August 1930|page=13|language=German|via=[[European Library]]}}</ref><ref name="straitstimes2" /> He was ranked number one French tennis player four times in a row in the consecutive years of 1934,<ref name="Pittspress">{{cite journal | date = 4 December 1934 | title = Boussus First in French Net | editor = | journal = [[The Pittsburgh Press]] | page = 26 | location = [[Pittsburgh]], United States | publisher = Press Publishing Company | editor-link = | volume = 51 | issue = 163 | accessdate = 15 September 2012 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=OgIdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oo4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4832,2603579&dq=boussus&hl=en }}</ref> 1935,<ref name="pittspost2">{{cite journal | date = 7 September 1935 | title = Net Matches opens here tomorrow | editor = | journal = [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | page = 12 | location = [[Pittsburgh]], United States | publisher = Paul Block | issn = 1068-624X | volume = 9 | issue = 33 | accessdate = 16 September 2012 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=saFhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JWkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=3812,6340315&dq=boussus+bickerton&hl=en }}</ref> 1936<ref name="pittspost">{{cite journal | date = 1 June 1936 | title = Perry extended to beat Boussus | editor = | journal = [[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]] | page = 20 | location = [[Pittsburgh]], United States | publisher = Paul Block | issn = 1068-624X | volume = 9 | issue = 263 | accessdate = 15 September 2012 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=OgIdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=oo4EAAAAIBAJ&pg=4832,2603579&dq=boussus&hl=en }}</ref> and 1937.<ref name="NYT">{{cite journal | journal = [[The New York Times]] | editor-last = | editor-first = | title = Boussus rated at top; Regains First Place in French Tennis—Destremeau Second | publisher = Ochs-Sulzberger family | location = New York, United States | url = http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F0081FFA3B5A157A93C6A81789D95F438385F9 | accessdate = 15 September 2012 | date = 17 December 1937 }}</ref>
Boussus was ranked World No. 9 in 1930 and 1935 by [[A. Wallis Myers]] of [[The Daily Telegraph]], and the European No. 6 in 1931 (the latter by "Züricher Sport" newspaper).<ref name="MontrealGazette1930" /><ref name="tennis&golf" /><ref name="ReadingEagle1935">[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=I7MhAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rZsFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3522,3593589&dq=wilmer-allison+world+ranking&hl=en "Moody, Perry Rated Tops By British Expert"], ''Reading Eagle'', 17 October 1935.</ref>
==Playing style== At the peak of his career in 1932 his play was observed by [[Great Britain Davis Cup Team|Great Britain]]'s then active Davis Cup player [[Nigel Sharpe]] who described him as the greatest French left-hander in the following manner: "He relies upon an all-round game with volleying as his forte. There is nothing of hurricane speed in his game. He takes the ball on the rise and hist his forehand with an easy swing and without much topspin. He gets good pace in this stroke and usually relies upon it as the forerunner of a volleying campaign[…]His backhand is of the cut variety but although putting so much slice on it he does not let it stop him from hitting it pretty hard. This stroke, of course, has its limitations, as it is distinctly difficult to make good passing shots against an agile volleyer. This wing is Boussus' chief weakness[…] (he) is able to make his volley down the line with great speed[..]but does not use his wrist quite so much". He further analysed his service game and found it be most unorthodox. Boussus completely omitted to swing his racquet behind his head while serving making his serves rather ineffective. Although this style was useful in overhead smashes when accuracy is more important than the speed. With this type of serve he also put a great spin to the ball and kept it relatively low.<ref name="straitstimes2" /> Later in his career he adapted to baseline play and utilized a series of dropshots in his games.<ref name="straitstimes">{{cite journal | editor = | url = http://newspapers.nl.sg/Digitised/Article.aspx?articleid=straitstimes19390519.2.161 | author = | authorlink = | issue = 14 | journal = [[The Straits Times]] | date = 19 May 1939 | title = China two down in Davis Cup | publisher = Straits Times Press | location = Singapore, [[Straits Settlements]] | page = 3 | accessdate = 17 September 2012 }}</ref>
==Personal life== In his student ages he studied advertising.<ref name="Sydneymh">{{cite journal | date = 17 December 1934 | title = The quiet Boussus | author = F. J. Perry | journal = [[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |trans-title=| location = Sydney, Australia | publisher = John Fairfax and Sons | author-link = Fred Perry | page = 5 | volume = | issue = 30251 | accessdate = 15 September 2012 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=m-pUAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6JEDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7312,5095823&dq=boussus+quiet&hl=en }}</ref> His 1930 season was interrupted because he had to fulfill his [[Military service#France|military service]].<ref name="straitstimes2" /> While playing amateur tennis he worked as a tire salesman in the mean time.<ref name="sport_parade">{{cite journal | date = 14 March 1932 | title = Sports parade | author = Henry McLemore | journal = [[Eugene Register-Guard]] | location = [[Eugene, Oregon|Eugene]], United States | publisher = Alton F. Baker, Sr. | author-link = | page = 4 | volume = 82 | issue = 74 | accessdate = 17 September 2012 | url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1310&dat=19320314&id=MbszAAAAIBAJ&sjid=WugDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6649,2391035 }}</ref> Later he was appointed the Director of Communications for [[IBM France]].<ref name="bagnerestennis" /> Apart from his tennis playing style he is known as the first man to wear shorts instead of pants on court.<ref name="figaro2">{{cite journal | date = 1 May 1936 | title = La mode rebondit aussi à Roland-Garros | editor = Alexis Brézet | journal = [[Le Figaro]] |trans-title=Fashion revives too at the Roland-Garros | location = Paris, France | publisher = [[Dassault Group]] | editor-link = | volume = | issn = 0182-5852 | accessdate = 15 September 2012 | url = http://madame.lefigaro.fr/style/mode-rebondit-aussi-roland-garros-230511-150158?page=2archive=BszTm8dCk78Jk8uwiNq9T8CoS9GECSHiKEu2xvmpVRWq3DUM%2F0JnHXKVP6wJb4SD6l65UtQFB%2BeZy6BaSOXVcw%3D%3D }}</ref><ref name="aucklandstar">{{cite journal | date = 26 November 1934 | title = Tennis Stars play in Auckland | editor = | journal = [[Auckland Star]] | page = 8 | location = [[Auckland]], New Zealand | publisher = | volume = 65 | issue = 280 | accessdate = 17 September 2012 | url = http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=EP19281008.2.22&srpos=22&e=--1927---1944--10--21----0boussus-- }}</ref> He was in a civil partnership with French parfume designer [[Germaine Cellier]] with whom he lived together for 30 years until she died in 1976.<ref name="SFdP">{{cite web | url = http://www.parfumeur-createur.com/article.php3?id_article=39 | title = Mme Cellier Germaine |trans-title=Mrs. Germaine Cellier | publisher = Société Française des Parfumeurs (French Society of Parfume Makers) | work = parfumeur-createur.com | date = | language = French | author = Jeannine Mongin | accessdate = 2012-09-15 | location = [[Versailles (city)|Versailles]], France }}</ref> He died at the age of 95, the last surviving Musketeer.<ref name="bagnerestennis" /> He had a brother Roland, also amateur tennis player, with whom he won the doubles title of the [[Le Touquet]] Spa Championships in 1937, while also winning the singles and mixed contest as well.<ref name="figaro3">{{cite journal | date = 1 August 1937 | title = Si J'étais entraineur de l'équipe de France | editor = Alexis Brézet | journal = [[Le Figaro]] |trans-title=If I was the coach of the French team | location = Paris, France | publisher = [[Dassault Group]] | author = K. Kamillom | volume = | issn = 0182-5852 | accessdate = 17 September 2012 | url = http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k4095788.textePage.f8.langFR | language = French }}</ref>

'''Cities for Life Day''' is a worldwide festivity that supports the abolition of the [[death penalty]]. It is celebrated on November 30 of each year.
==History== [[Cesare Beccaria]] was one of the greatest Italian [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] writers, who was noted for his masterpiece ''Of Crimes and Punishments'' (1764), which was later translated into 22 languages. In it, Beccaria put forth some of the first modern arguments against the [[death penalty]]. His treatise was also the first full work of penology, advocating reform of the criminal law system. The book was the first full-scale work to tackle criminal reform and to suggest that criminal justice should conform to rational principles.
As a consequence in [[Italy]] the first pre-unitarian state to abolish the [[death penalty]] was the [[Grand Duchy of Tuscany]] as of November 30, 1786, under the reign of [[Pietro Leopoldo|Pietro Leopoldo, later Holy Roman Emperor Leopold II]]. So Tuscany was the first civil state in the world to do away with torture and capital punishment.
Since then in the last two centuries the refusal of death penalty has been increasing all around the world:
"In 2012, 141 states have abolished either by law or on a de facto basis the death penalty, while it is still on the books in 51 countries. Since 2007, the United Nations General Assembly has repeatedly called for a universal moratorium with a view toward total abolition of capital punishment. In 2011 progress was made in all regions of the world, particularly the United States: Illinois became abolitionist and in April 2012 Connecticut became the 17th state to abolish the death penalty, thus becoming the fifth American state to revoke capital punishment in the last five years."[http://nodeathpenalty.santegidio.org/pageID/247/langID/en/The-International-Day-of-Cities-for-life--cities-against-the-death-penalty.html]
==Characteristics== On the "Cities for Life Day", November 30, many important cities<ref>[http://nodeathpenalty.santegidio.org/pag.aspx?ln=en&id=11 The cities / No to death penalty − Community of Sant'Egidio] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110108140330/http://nodeathpenalty.santegidio.org/pag.aspx?ln=en&id=11 |date=2011-01-08 }}. Nodeathpenalty.santegidio.org. Retrieved on 2010-11-30.</ref><ref>[http://nodeathpenalty.santegidio.org/pag.aspx?ln=en&id=4 Cities For Life] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091227065102/http://nodeathpenalty.santegidio.org/pag.aspx?ln=en&id=4 |date=2009-12-27 }}, Nodeathpenalty.santegidio.org. Retrieved on 2010-11-30.</ref> around the world celebrate the first abolition of the [[death penalty]] by a [[Europe]]an state, decreed by [[Leopold II, Holy Roman Emperor]] of [[Habsburg|Habsburg-Lorraine]] in 1786 for his Grand Duchy of [[Tuscany]]. On this occasion the participating cities show their commitment for life and against the death penalty.
On this day, participating cities illuminate a symbolic monument, such as the [[Atomium]] in [[Brussels]], the [[Colosseum]] in [[Rome]] and the [[Plaza de Santa Ana]] in [[Madrid]]. Participating cities in 2009 include more than 60 [[Capital (political)|capitals]] worldwide, and over 1,200 cities and towns around the world, such as Rome, Brussels, [[Madrid]], [[Ottawa]], [[Mexico City]], [[Berlin]], [[Barcelona]], [[Florence]], [[Venice]], [[Buenos Aires]], [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Dallas]], [[Antwerp]], [[Vienna]], [[Naples]], [[Paris]], [[Copenhagen]], [[Stockholm]], [[Reggio Emilia]], [[Bogotá]], [[Santiago de Chile]].
By this symbolic action, these cities demand a stay of all [[execution (legal)|executions]] worldwide. This initiative is promoted by the [[Community of Sant'Egidio]] and supported by the main international human rights organizations, gathered in the [[World Coalition Against the Death Penalty]] ([[Amnesty International]], [[Ensemble contre la Peine de Mort]], [[International Penal Reform]], [[FIACAT]]).
In 2005, the Cities for Life Day also featured the "Africa for Life" conference about the death penalty in [[Africa]], in which 14 [[minister of justice|ministers of justice]] from as many African countries participated. The conference took place in [[Florence]], [[Tuscany]].
Cities continue to join this cause, many in countries that maintain the death penalty.<ref>[http://nodeathpenalty.santegidio.org/en/photos/mappe.aspx Map] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019142719/http://nodeathpenalty.santegidio.org/en/photos/mappe.aspx |date=2013-10-19 }}</ref> In 2012 there were 1625, of which 72 were capitals.<ref>[http://nodeathpenalty.santegidio.org/it/le-citta.aspx List of the Cities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131019144636/http://nodeathpenalty.santegidio.org/it/le-citta.aspx |date=2013-10-19 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Death penalty]] *[[World Coalition Against the Death Penalty]] *[[Community of Sant'Egidio]]

{{Infobox military person |name=David Ernest Hornell |image=VCDavidErnestHornell.jpg |caption=F/L David Ernest Hornell |birth_date= 26 January 1910 |death_date= {{death-date and age|24 June 1944|26 January 1910}} |birth_place=[[Mimico]], [[Ontario]] |death_place=[[North Atlantic]] |placeofburial=[[Lerwick]] Cemetery, [[Shetland]] |nickname= |allegiance=[[Canada]] |branch=[[Royal Canadian Air Force]] |serviceyears=1941–1944 |rank=[[Flight Lieutenant]] |unit=No. 162 Squadron RCAF |commands= |awards=[[Victoria Cross]] |family= }} [[File:Gravestone of David Ernest Hornell.jpg|thumb|300px|Hornell's burial site in [[Shetland]], Scotland]] '''David Ernest Hornell''' VC (26 January 1910 – 24 June 1944) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] recipient of the [[Victoria Cross]], the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to [[United Kingdom|British]] and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] forces.
==Early life== David "Bud" Hornell was born on Toronto Island and spent his later childhood and adolescence in the Toronto suburb of [[Mimico]]. He attended [[Mimico High School]], having obtained the Fred Werden scholarship, given in memory of the son of Mimico's postmaster, who was killed in the First World War.<ref>''The Mimico Story'', Harvey Currell, 1967, p. 90</ref>
==Second World War== He enlisted in the [[Royal Canadian Air Force]] in January 1941, and received his pilot's wings in September the same year. After further instruction in [[Charlottetown]], [[Prince Edward Island]], he was posted to the Royal Canadian Air Force station on North Vancouver Island. Commissioned in 1942, Flight Lieutenant Hornell completed 60 operational missions, involving some 600 hours flying.
===Victoria Cross=== Flight Lieutenant Hornell was flying as aircraft captain on a [[Consolidated PBY Catalina|Consolidated Canso]]<ref name=CMP>{{cite web |url=http://www.cmp-cpm.forces.gc.ca/dhh-dhp/gal/vcg-gcv/bio/hornell-de-eng.asp |title=Victoria Cross - Second World War, 1939-1945: David Ernest Hornell |publisher=[[Chief of Military Personnel (Canada)|Chief of Military Personnel]], [[Department of National Defence (Canada)|Department of National Defence]], Canada}}</ref> amphibian aircraft with [[No. 162 Squadron RCAF|162 (Bomber Reconnaissance) Squadron, RCAF]], from [[Wick Airport#RAF Wick|RAF Wick]] in Northern Scotland, when the following action took place for which he was awarded the VC.
On 24 June 1944 on sea patrol near the [[Faroes]] in the North [[Atlantic]], Hornell's aircraft was attacked and badly damaged by the {{GS|U-1225}}. Nevertheless he and his crew succeeded in sinking the submarine. Hornell then managed to bring his burning aircraft down on the heavy swell. There was only one serviceable dinghy, which could not hold all the crew, so they took turns in the cold water.
By the time the survivors were rescued 21 hours later, Hornell was blinded and weak from exposure and cold. He died shortly after being picked up. He is buried in [[Lerwick]] Cemetery, Shetland Islands.<ref name=VCO>{{cite web |url=http://www.homeusers.prestel.co.uk/stewart/scotland.htm |title=Grave Location ''[sic]'' for Victoria Cross Holders in: Scotland |publisher=victoriacross.org.uk |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20041028142235/http://www.homeusers.prestel.co.uk/stewart/scotland.htm |archivedate=2004-10-28 |df= }}</ref>
====Citation==== {{quote|Flight Lieutenant Hornell was captain and first pilot of a twin-engined amphibian aircraft engaged on an anti-submarine patrol in northern waters. The patrol had lasted for some hours when a fully-surfaced U-boat was sighted, travelling at high speed on the port beam. Flight Lieutenant Hornell at once turned to the attack.
The U-boat altered course. The aircraft had been seen and there could be no surprise. The U-boat opened up with anti-aircraft fire which became increasingly fierce and accurate.
At a range of 1,200 yards, the front guns of the aircraft replied; then its starboard guns jammed, leaving only one gun effective. Hits were obtained on and around the conning-tower of the U-boat, but the aircraft was itself hit, two large holes appearing in the starboard wing.
Ignoring the enemy’s fire, Flight Lieutenant Hornell carefully manoeuvred for the attack. Oil was pouring from his starboard engine, which was, by this time, on fire, as was the starboard wing; and the petrol tanks were endangered. Meanwhile, the aircraft was hit again and again by the U-boat’s guns. Holed in many places, it was vibrating violently and very difficult to control.
Nevertheless, the captain decided to press home his attack, knowing that with every moment the chances of escape for him and his gallant crew would grow more slender. He brought his aircraft down very low and released his depth charges in a perfect straddle. The bows of the U-boat were lifted out of the water; it sank and the crew were seen in the sea.
Flight Lieutenant Hornell contrived, by superhuman efforts at the controls, to gain a little height. The fire in the starboard wing had grown more intense and the vibration had increased. Then the burning engine fell off. The plight of aircraft and crew was now desperate. With the utmost coolness, the captain took his aircraft into wind and, despite the manifold dangers, brought it safely down on the heavy swell. Badly damaged and blazing furiously, the aircraft rapidly settled.
After ordeal by fire came ordeal by water. There was only one serviceable dinghy and this could not hold all the crew. So they took turns in the water, holding on to the sides. Once, the dinghy capsized in the rough seas and was righted only with great difficulty. Two of the crew succumbed from exposure.
An airborne lifeboat was dropped to them but fell some 500 yards down wind. The men struggled vainly to reach it and Flight Lieutenant Hornell, who throughout had encouraged them by his cheerfulness and inspiring leadership, proposed to swim to it, through he was nearly exhausted. He was with difficulty restrained. The survivors were finally rescued after they had been in the water for 21 hours. By this time Flight Lieutenant Hornell was blinded and completely exhausted. He died shortly after being picked up.
Flight Lieutenant Hornell had completed 60 operational missions, involving 600 hours’ flying. He well knew the danger and difficulties attending attacks on submarines. By pressing home a skilful and successful attack against fierce opposition, with his aircraft in a precarious condition, and by fortifying and encouraging his comrades in the subsequent ordeal, this officer displayed valour and devotion to duty of the highest order.<ref name=CMP/><ref>{{London Gazette |issue= 36630|date=25 July 1944|page=3523|supp=y}}</ref>}}
==Legacy== [[File:Consolidated Canso RCAF 9754.jpg|thumb|300px|Hornell's memorial Canso in 2018]] [[David Hornell Junior School]], an elementary school in Mimico is named after him.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tdsb.on.ca/FindYour/Schools.aspx?schno=2078 |title=David Hornell Junior School (GR. JK-05) |publisher=[[Toronto District School Board]] |accessdate=11 September 2014}}</ref>
The Canso aircraft in the collection of the [[Canadian Warplane Heritage Museum]] in Hamilton, Ontario, was restored in the colours and markings of 162 (Bomber Reconnaissance) Squadron and dedicated to the memory of Flight Lieutenant David Hornell, VC.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.warplane.com/pages/aircraft_canso.html |title=Consolidated PBY-5A Canso |publisher=Canadian Heritage Warplane Museum}}</ref>
A squadron of the [[Royal Canadian Air Cadets]] in the west end of Toronto, Ontario, is named after him.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.700sqn.com |title=700 David Hornell VC Squadron}}</ref>
A [[Toronto Island Airport]] ferry is named after Hornell <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.torontoport.com/About-TPA/Media-Room/Press-Releases/Winning-names-for-Billy-Bishop-Toronto-City-Airpor.aspx|publisher=Toronto Port Authority|title=Winning names for Billy Bishop Toronto City Airport vessels announced by Toronto Port Authority|date=1 July 2010|accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref>
The Wing Operations building at CFB 14 Wing Greenwood, Nova Scotia, Canada is named after Hornell.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dsra.ca/projects/hornell-centre|publisher=DSRA|title= Hornell Centre 14 Wing Greenwood, NS |accessdate=12 September 2014}}</ref>
His Victoria Cross is on loan to 1 Canadian Air Division Headquarters in [[Winnipeg]] and is on display at the Air Force Heritage Museum.<ref name=VCO/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
