{{Infobox writer | name = Dinah Abrahamson | honorific_prefix = | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1954 | birth_place = [[Omaha, Nebraska]], [[United States]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2013|12|17|1954|1|01}}{{cite web|url=http://www.collive.com/show_news.rtx?id=28228&alias=dinah-abrahamson-59-obm|title=Dinah Abrahamson, 59, OBM|first=Chabad On|last=Line|website=collive|accessdate=18 July 2017}} | death_place = [[Brooklyn, New York]], United States | resting_place = | occupation = Author/Nebraska State Central Committee Member | language = | education = | alma_mater = | period = 2011-2013 | genre = [[Race relations]] | subject = | movement = | notableworks = | spouse = | partner = | children = Sarah Abrahamson
Yosef Abrahamson | relatives = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | years_active = 2011-2013 | module = | website = {{URL|https://theabrahamsonfamily.wordpress.com/}} | portaldisp = }} '''Dinah Abrahamson''' (1954{{spaced ndash}}December 17, 2013) was an American author and politician. A native of [[Omaha, Nebraska]], Abrahamson was a member of the Nebraska State Central Committee as well as an active member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. She was also known for her appearance on the [[Oprah Winfrey Network (U.S. TV channel)|Oprah Winfrey Network]] special on the lives of [[Hasidic Jews]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lsKaYu4-dM0|title=Oprah Meets a Black Hasidic Family - Oprah's Next Chapter - Oprah Winfrey Network|first=|last=OWN|date=12 February 2012|publisher=|accessdate=18 July 2017|via=YouTube}} Abrahamson and her family were most memorable for being one of few [[African American]] families associated with the [[Chabad Lubavitch]] movement.{{cite news|last1=|first1=|title=A Young Man From Omaha, Who May Perfectly Represent Brooklyn|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/16/nyregion/16bigcity.html|accessdate=|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 16, 2008}} ==Early life== Abrahamson was born in [[Omaha, Nebraska]] in 1954, the daughter of immigrants. Her father was of [[Afro-Panamanian]] descent and her mother was caucasian of [[Ashkenazi Jewish]] descent from Germany. Raised by her mother and maternal grandparents, Abrahamson grew up in a secular Jewish household and would only attend [[synagogue]] on events within the Jewish community.{{cite news|last1=Martin|first1=Michel|title=Black Family Bears Unique Jewish Distinction|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=92230958|accessdate=July 18, 2017|publisher=[[NPR]]|date=July 4, 2008|language=en}} ==Religious views== In 1993, Abrahamson and her two children joined the Hasidic Jewish dynasty, Chabad Lubavitch.{{cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=92230958|title=Black Family Bears Unique Jewish Distinction|website=npr.org|accessdate=18 July 2017}} After being raised in a secular household, Abrahamson became religious as she grew older and got to know herself better. The Abrahamsons were one of few Hasidic families, let alone black Hasidic families, in the Omaha area. Her daughter Sarah eventually moved to Brooklyn, New York to work at a Hasidic Jewish day school. Shortly afterwards, Abrahamson and her son Yosef joined Sarah in New York City in order to be closer to a larger Jewish community.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/16/nyregion/16bigcity.html|title=A Young Man From Omaha, Who May Perfectly Represent Brooklyn|first=Susan|last=Dominus|date=16 June 2008|publisher=|accessdate=18 July 2017|via=NYTimes.com}} The family ultimately settled in [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn|Crown Heights]], a neighborhood known for both its large African-American and Hasidic Jewish communities who live side by side in the area. ==Politics== Abrahamson was an active member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]]. She was a member of the Nebraska State Central Committee, as well as a supporter of Nebraska politician [[Lee Terry]] who was a family friend of Abrahamson. ==Writing== At the time of her death, Abrahamson had self-published a book on race relations in America. ==Death== Abrahamson died on December 17, 2013. She was survived by her children, her sister, and a granddaughter. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Sources== {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Abrahamson, Dinah}} [[Category:1954 births]] [[Category:Date of birth missing]] [[Category:2013 deaths]] [[Category:African-American Jews]] [[Category:African-American women in politics]] [[Category:African-American writers]] [[Category:American writers]] [[Category:African-American women writers]] [[Category:American women writers]] [[Category:American Orthodox Jews]] [[Category:American people of German-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American people of Panamanian descent]] [[Category:Jewish women writers]] [[Category:Nebraska Republicans]] [[Category:Politicians from Omaha, Nebraska]] [[Category:People from Brooklyn]] [[Category:People from Crown Heights, Brooklyn]] [[Category:African-American people in Nebraska politics]] [[Category:Writers from Omaha, Nebraska]]

{{Other uses}} [[Image:Dybbuk.jpg|thumb|300px|Dybbuk, by [[Ephraim Moses Lilien|Ephraim Moshe Lilien]] (1874–1925).]]
In [[Jewish mythology]], a '''dybbuk''' ({{lang-yi|דיבוק}}, from the [[Hebrew]] verb {{hebrew|דָּבַק}} ''dāḇaq'' meaning "adhere" or "cling") is a malicious [[spiritual possession|possessing]] [[spiritual being|spirit]] believed to be the dislocated [[soul]] of a dead person. It supposedly leaves the host body once it has accomplished its goal, sometimes after being [[Exorcism#Judaism|helped]].<ref name="Falk">[https://books.google.com/books?id=z10-Xz9Kno4C&lpg=PA538&ots=aitC-oaSO_&dq=dybbuk&pg=PA538#v=onepage&q=dybbuk&f=false A Psychoanalytic History of the Jews, by Avner Falk, p.538, Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press, 1996]</ref><ref>{{Citation| contribution=Dybbuk| contribution-url=http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/174964/dybbuk| title=Encyclopædia Britannica Online| url=http://www.britannica.com/| accessdate=2009-06-10}}</ref><ref name="EJ">[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0005_0_05197.html "Dibbuk", Encyclopedia Judaica], by [[Gershom Scholem]].</ref>
==Etymology== "'''Dybbuk'''" is an abbreviation of {{Hebrew|דיבוק מרוח רעה}} ''dibbūq mē-rūaḥ rā‘ā'' ("a cleavage of an evil spirit"), or {{Hebrew|דיבוק מן החיצונים}} ''dibbūq min ha-ḥīṣōnīm'' ("dibbuk from the outside"), which is found in man. "Dybbuk" comes from the Hebrew word {{hebrew|דִּיבּוּק}} ''dibbūq'' which means "the act of sticking" and is a nominal form derived from the verb {{hebrew|דָּבַק}} ''dāḇaq'' "to adhere" or "cling".<ref>See [https://books.google.nl/books?id=EZCgpaTgLm0C&pg=PA187&lpg=PA187&dq=%22qittul%22+pattern&source=bl&ots=YfozMVFICC&sig=GDMTg-xNYuhKvxBeYSucLRi8VWI&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0CDkQ6AEwBWoVChMIqJilgcWFyQIVC3EUCh2TCgTl#v=onepage&q=%22qittul%22%20pattern&f=false A. Sáenz-Badillos & J. Elwolde, ''A History of the Hebrew Language'', 1996, p. 187] on the ''qiṭṭūl'' pattern.</ref>
==History== The term first appears in a number of 16th century writings,<ref name="Falk" /><ref name="Goldish">[https://books.google.com/books?id=CF1C84xHeucC&lpg=PA41&ots=CvbxBG1z6W&dq=dybbuk&pg=PA41#v=onepage&q=dybbuk&f=false ''Spirit Possession in Judaism: Cases and Contexts from the Middle Ages to the Present, by Matt Goldish'', p.41, Wayne State University Press, 2003]</ref> though it was ignored by mainstream scholarship until [[S. Ansky]]'s play ''[[The Dybbuk]]'' popularised the concept in literary circles.<ref name="Goldish" /> Earlier accounts of possession (such as that given by [[Josephus]]) were of demonic possession rather than that by ghosts.<ref name="Schwartz">[https://books.google.com/books?id=60iVk1p8Y9IC&lpg=PA229&ots=WYDSSzpy-j&dq=dybbuk&pg=PA229#v=onepage&q=dybbuk&f=false ''Tree of Souls:The Mythology of Judaism'', by Howard Schwartz, pp. 229–230, Oxford University Press, 1 Nov 2004]</ref> These accounts advocated orthodoxy among the populace<ref name="Falk" /> as a preventative measure. For example, it was suggested that a sloppily made [[mezuzah]] or entertaining doubt about [[Crossing the Red Sea|Moses' crossing of the Red Sea]] opened one's household to dybbuk possession. Very precise details of names and locations have been included in accounts of dybbuk possession. Rabbi [[Yoel Teitelbaum]], the [[Satmar (Hasidic dynasty)|Satmar rebbe]] (1887–1979) is reported to have supposedly advised an individual said to be possessed to consult a [[psychiatrist]].<ref name="Schwartz" />
Ansky's play is a significant work of [[Yiddish theatre]], and has been adapted a number of times by writers, composers and other creators including [[Jerome Robbins]]/[[Leonard Bernstein]] and [[Tony Kushner]]. In the play, a young bride is possessed by the ghost of the man she was meant to marry, had her father not broken a marriage agreement.
There are other forms of soul transmigration in Jewish mythology. In contrast to the dybbuk, the [[ibbur]] (meaning "impregnation") is a positive possession, which happens when a righteous soul temporarily possesses a body. This is always done with consent, so that the soul can perform a [[mitzvah]]. The [[gilgul]] ({{lang-he|גלגול הנשמות}}, literally "rolling") puts forth the idea that a soul must live through many lives before it gains the wisdom to rejoin with God.
In psychological literature the Dybbuk has been described as an [[Hysteria|hysterical]] syndrome.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Billu | first1 = Y | last2 = Beit-Hallahmi | first2 = B | year = 1989 | title = Dybbuk-Possession as a hysterical symptom: Psychodynamic and socio-cultural factors | url = | journal = Israel Journal of Psychiatry and Related Science | volume = 26 | issue = | pages = 138–149 | pmid = 2606645 }}</ref>
== In popular culture == ===Film===
The [[Malayalam]] movie ''[[Ezra (2017 film)|Ezra]]'' (2017) revolves around a Dybbuk box, with references to Kabbalist traditions and occultism.
[[Michał Waszyński]]'s 1937 film ''[[The Dybbuk (film)|The Dybbuk]]'', based on the Yiddish play by [[S. Ansky]], is considered one of the classics of [[Yiddish cinema|Yiddish film-making]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The Dybbuk|url=http://www.jewishfilm.org/Catalogue/films/dybbuk.html|publisher=[[The National Center for Jewish Film]]|accessdate=29 October 2014}}</ref>
The dybbuk was featured as the main antagonist in the horror films ''[[The Unborn (2009 film)|The Unborn]]'' (2009) and ''[[The Possession (2012 film)|The Possession]]'' (2012).
In ''[[Love and Death]]'', [[Woody Allen]]'s 1975 satire of Russian literature, Boris (Allen) flirts with Sonja ([[Diane Keaton]]), who is with the fish monger she is set to marry. The fiancée keeps getting in the way of Boris' advances, which leads him to ask Sonja, "Did you have to bring the dybbuk?"
''[[A Serious Man]]'' opens with a story about a couple who suspect that the rabbi they're hosting for dinner is a dybbuk.
[[Marcin Wrona]]'s ''[[Demon (2015 film)|Demon]]'' is the story of a groom possessed by a dybbuk the night before his wedding.
In the [[Christopher Guest]] 1997 movie ''[[Waiting for Guffman]]'', dentist Allan Pearl discusses his family history with show business: "I think I got a, a, an entertaining bug... from my grandfather... uh, Chaim Pearlgut, who was very very big in the, um, Yiddish, uh, theater, back in New York. He was in the, the very... the sardonically irreverent... "Dybbuk Shmybbuk, I Said 'More Ham'" ... and that revue I believe was 1914, and that revue was what made him famous. Incidentally, the song "Bubbe Made A Kishke" came from that revue."
===Print=== In [[Romain Gary]]'s 1967 novel ''The Dance of Genghis Cohn'', a [[Nazi concentration camps|concentration camp]] warden is haunted by the dybbuk of one of his victims.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Schwartz|first1=Howard| authorlink =Howard Schwartz|title=Reimagining the Bible: The Storytelling of the Rabbis|date=1998|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195104998|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=K8X2DymK5UcC&pg=PA76&lpg=PA76&dq=dyke+dybbuk&source=bl&ots=-ODnZU4j5e&sig=ALuneEdEJb7o71S3MJRGXjamXO4&hl=en&sa=X&ei=2y1RVMv6McflaLHSgNgP&ved=0CE4Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=dyke%20dybbuk&f=false|ref=Schwartz}}</ref>
In [[Ellen Galford]]'s 1993 novel ''The Dyke and the Dybbuk'', lesbian taxi-driver Rainbow Rosenbloom is haunted by, and gets the better of, a female dybbuk haunting her as a result of a curse placed on her ancestor 200 years ago.<ref name=Schwartz />
The dybbuk appears in the fictional novel, ''The Inquisitor's Apprentice'' (2011) by [[Chris Moriarty]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/13/books/review/books-about-young-crimefighters-in-new-york.html|title=Books About Young Crimefighters in New York|last=Bird|first=Elizabeth|access-date=2018-08-19|language=en}}</ref>
In the comic series ''[[Girl Genius]]'', the forcible insertion of the mind of Agatha's mother, the main villain Lucrezia Mongfish/"The Other", into her own was compared to a dybbuk by one of her followers when reporting the situation to someone else.
[[Richard Zimler]]'s 2011 novel ''[[The Warsaw Anagrams]]'' is narrated by a dybbuk desperately trying to understand why he has remained in our world. This is in keeping with kabbalistic belief that dybbuks fail to pass over to the Other Side because of a [[mitzvah]] or duty that they have failed to fulfill.
===Television===
The Dybbuk is mentioned in the paranormal TV show ''[[Paranormal Witness]]'', season 2, episode 4 "The Dybbuk Box".
The "Dybbuk Box" was shown on the first episode of ''[[Deadly Possessions]]'' (spin off of Ghost Adventures). In which the son of the relative of a holocaust survivor accounts the tale of the Dybbuks' attachment to the deaths relating around the box.
In the TV show ''[[Difficult People]]'', season 3, episode 3 [[Difficult People#Season 3 .282017.29|"Code Change]]", Billy helps his sister-in-law Rucchel exorcise what she perceives to be a Dybbuk from her basement.
In the episode of ''[[The Real Ghostbusters]]'', "Drool, the Dog-faced Goblin," the Ghostbusters discuss with Peter Venkman the many different forms an antagonistic ghost they are facing can take, with Egon Spengler mentioning a dybbuk. Peter asks Egon what a dybbuk is with Egon replying it's best if he didn't know. In a later episode titled "The Devil to Pay," the Ghostbusters deal with a demon named Dib Devlin who swindles Ray Stanz and Winston Zeddemore into selling their souls to compete in his game show. Dib Devlin is later revealed to be a dybbuk.
Grandpa Boris tells a scary story to the babies involving a Dybbuk in an early episode of ''[[Rugrats]]''.

{{good article}} {{Infobox video game |title = Ethnic Cleansing |image = EC Title Screen.png |image_size = 275px |caption = Title screen |developer = [[National Alliance (United States)|National Alliance]] |publisher = [[Resistance Records]] |engine = [[Genesis3D]] |released = January 21, 2002 |genre = [[First-person shooter]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows]] }} {{Antisemitism}} '''''Ethnic Cleansing''''' is a [[first-person shooter]] video game for [[Microsoft Windows]] computers, created by the American [[White supremacy|White supremacist]] organization [[National Alliance (United States)|National Alliance]] (and published by its record label [[Resistance Records]]) on January 21, 2002. As part of a "[[Race war|Race War]]", the player controls a [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazi]] skinhead or a [[Ku Klux Klan|Klansman]] and is tasked with killing stereotypical [[African-American]], [[Mexican-American|Mexican]], and [[Jewish-American|Jewish]] enemies, ending with then-[[Israel]]i Prime Minister [[Ariel Sharon]].
Using the [[Genesis3D]] engine, the National Alliance created the game to be provocative and to support their white supremacist message. The game has been controversial, with the [[Anti-Defamation League]] taking particular issue; it has been ranked several times as one of the most controversial games ever created. It was planned to be followed by a long line of sequels, but only one, titled ''White Law'', has been released.
==Gameplay== ''Ethnic Cleansing'' is a standard, short-length [[first-person shooter]] set in a single [[Level (video gaming)|level]]. The player can select a [[Neo-Nazism|neo-Nazi]], a [[White power skinhead|Skinhead]], or a [[Ku Klux Klan|Klansman]] to control. They run through a [[ghetto]] that has been compared to [[New York City]] and shoot [[African-American]]s and [[Mexican American|Mexican]]s, before descending into a subway system to kill [[Jewish-Americans|Jews]]. Finally, the player reaches the "[[Zionist Occupied Government|Yiddish Control Center]]", where a fictionalized version of [[Ariel Sharon]], then [[Prime Minister of Israel|Prime Minister]] of [[Israel]], is directing plans for world domination.<ref name="pop"/><ref name="wired"/><ref name="ugo"/> He carries a [[rocket launcher]]; the player must kill him to complete the game.<ref name="eurogamer"/> The [[HUD (video gaming)|heads-up]] display contains a map of nearby enemies and a counter of remaining ammunition.<ref name="game">{{cite video game|title=Ethnic Cleansing|publisher=[[Resistance Records]]|developer=[[National Alliance (United States)|National Alliance]]|date=January 21, 2002}}</ref>
The game's soundtrack consists of [[White power music#White power rock|white power rock music]]. The game's art assets and sound effects feature [[ethnic stereotype|racial stereotypes]]: when shot, black enemies make monkey noises and Jewish enemies are dressed as [[rabbi]]s and shout "[[oy vey]]!".<ref name="wired"/> Mexican characters shout "I need to take a siesta now". In addition, black enemies are drawn to resemble apes<ref name="stuff"/> and some wear T-shirts with the lettering "[[Nigga|NIGZ]]",<ref name="ugo"/> while Mexican enemies wear [[sombrero]]s.<ref name="stuff"/>
==Development and release== {{Quote box|quote="The Race War has begun. Your skin is your uniform in this battle for the survival of your kind. The White Race depends on you to secure its existence. Your peoples {{sic}} enemies surround you in a sea of decay and filth that they have brought to your once clean and [[White Americans|White]] nation.
Not one of their numbers shall be spared..."|source=—Tagline from Resistance's website<ref name="website">{{cite web|url=http://resistance.com/catalog/product_info.php?cPath=28&products_id=203&osCsid=36cbed8ae26c5069b6ad2724dbdb266d|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051115022908/http://resistance.com/catalog/product_info.php?cPath=28&products_id=203&osCsid=36cbed8ae26c5069b6ad2724dbdb266d|archivedate=November 15, 2005|publisher=[[Resistance Records|Resistance.com]]|title=ETHNIC CLEANSING [866]|accessdate=October 21, 2014}}</ref>|width=330px|align=left}}
''Ethnic Cleansing'' was developed by members of the [[National Alliance (United States)|National Alliance]], an American [[white supremacy|white supremacist]] organization, and published by [[Resistance Records]], its subsidiary record label that specializes in [[white power music]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://openjurist.org/476/f3d/719/united-states-v-ross|publisher=OpenJurist|title=476 F. 3d 719 - United States v. Ross|date=February 8, 2007|accessdate=October 21, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140813085004/http://openjurist.org/476/f3d/719/united-states-v-ross|archive-date=2014-08-13|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> It was developed for [[Microsoft Windows]] personal computers using Eclipse Entertainment's [[open-source software|open-source]] game engine [[Genesis3D]] along with the Reality Factory development kit. The source code was not substantially changed from the original. Instead, the developers simply plugged in images and sounds that they had created in freely available editing programs.<ref name="promote hate"/>
Shaun Walker, the chairman of the National Alliance, explained to the [[United Press]] that the intent was to produce a racially provocative video game and promote [[racial segregation]].<ref name="eurogamer">{{cite web|last=Gibson|first=Ellie|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/news180705racists|publisher=[[Eurogamer]]|title=Racists launch PC game|date=July 18, 2005|accessdate=October 21, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141026055233/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/news180705racists|archive-date=2014-10-26|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> National Alliance founder [[William Luther Pierce]], who also appears in the game to discuss an "upcoming [[European Americans|white]] revolution", considered video games to be simply another medium to promote his organization's messages. Resistance released the game on [[Martin Luther King, Jr. Day]] (January 21) of 2002.<ref name="wired"/><ref name="promote hate">{{cite web|url=http://www.adl.org/assets/pdf/combating-hate/Racist-groups-use-computer-gaming.pdf|format=PDF|publisher=[[Anti-Defamation League]]|title=Racist Groups Use Computer Gaming to Promote Hate|accessdate=October 21, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131105220545/http://www.adl.org/assets/pdf/combating-hate/Racist-groups-use-computer-gaming.pdf|archive-date=2013-11-05|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> It was priced at [[U.S. dollar|USD $]]14.88,<ref name="wired"/> a reference to the white supremacist [[Fourteen Words]] slogan and the neo-Nazi numerical code "88" (which stands for "HH" or "Heil Hitler").
==Reception and controversy== [[File:Ethnic Cleansing shot.png|thumb|left|275px|Here, the player shoots two African-American men. The game received backlash for its racist themes.]] While it received little attention from the mainstream media, the game was immediately controversial among Americans on both sides of the political spectrum.<ref name="pop">{{cite web|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091208065556/http://www.popmatters.com/multimedia/features/040226-whitesupremacists.shtml|url=http://www.popmatters.com/multimedia/features/040226-whitesupremacists.shtml|last=Leonard|first=David|title=White Supremacist Games or Just More of the Same?|date=February 26, 2004|publisher=[[PopMatters]]|archivedate=December 8, 2009|accessdate=October 21, 2014}}</ref> The [[Anti-Defamation League]], an [[anti-racism|anti-racist]] organization that especially covers [[anti-Semitism]], publicized the existence of the game and unsuccessfully lobbied the developers of Genesis3D to change their licensing conditions to prohibit the use of the engine to develop racist games. They lobbied the [[Interactive Digital Software Association]] to encourage its members to adopt such policies.<ref name="promote hate"/>
The game's reception from critics was extremely negative. David Leonard of [[PopMatters]] described the game's graphics and "playability". While not approving of the game's message, he argued that it was only the latest in a long line of racist video games that included the likes of ''[[Grand Theft Auto III]]'', ''[[NFL Street]]'', and ''[[Freedom Fighters (video game)|Freedom Fighters]]''.<ref name="pop"/> In January 2003, ''[[Stuff (magazine)|Stuff]]'' named ''Ethnic Cleansing'' the 40th most controversial video game of all time. The staff opined that only "very stupid children" would be susceptible to its message and that it would make players feel like "small-minded assholes".<ref name="stuff">{{cite journal|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/8043349/50-Most-Controversial-Games-Ever-Stuff-Magazine-200X|title=50 Most Controversial Games Ever|journal=[[Stuff (magazine)|Stuff]]|date=January 2003|page=75|access-date=2017-09-09|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305160325/https://www.scribd.com/doc/8043349/50-Most-Controversial-Games-Ever-Stuff-Magazine-200X|archive-date=2016-03-05|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> ''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]''<ref name="complex">{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2012/06/the-10-most-racist-video-games/|publisher=''[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]''|title=The 10 Most Racist Video Games|accessdate=October 21, 2014|last=Hester|first=Larry|date=June 20, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141021100656/http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2012/06/the-10-most-racist-video-games/|archive-date=2014-10-21|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> and ''[[UGO]]'' ranked it as the single most racist video game in history. ''UGO'' staff writer K. Thor Jensen called it "profoundly stupid".<ref name="ugo">{{cite web|url=http://www.ugo.com/games/ethnic-cleansing|publisher=[[UGO]]|last=Jensen|first=K. Thor|title=The 11 Most Racist Video Games|date=November 30, 2010|accessdate=October 21, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120128214108/http://www.ugo.com/games/ethnic-cleansing|archivedate=January 28, 2012}}</ref>
Pierce estimated that "a couple thousand" copies of the game had been sold within a month of its release and that 90 percent of consumers had been white teenage boys.<ref name="wired"/>
==Sequel== The National Alliance and Resistance Records released a similar game, ''White Law'', in June 2003. It starred an [[Irish-American]] police officer taking up arms to protect his territory from racial minorities. It has been compared to [[Freedom Fighters (video game)|''Freedom Fighters'']],<ref name="pop"/> though it was based on the events of Pierce's novel ''[[The Turner Diaries]]''. The National Alliance intended to create an entire line of racist games, but no more have surfaced.<ref name="wired">{{cite web|url=http://archive.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2002/02/50523|last=Scheeres|first=Julia|title=Games Elevate Hate to Next Level|date=February 20, 2002|accessdate=October 21, 2014|publisher=''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140929044711/http://archive.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2002/02/50523|archive-date=2014-09-29|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.adl.org/presrele/internet_75/4042_72.html#.VEX9gvldWSo|publisher=Anti-Defamation League|date=February 19, 2002|title=ADL Report: Growing Proliferation of Racist Video Games Target Youth on The Internet|accessdate=October 21, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140817194717/http://archive.adl.org/presrele/internet_75/4042_72.html#.VEX9gvldWSo|archive-date=2014-08-17|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref>

revision.text:
'''HIV in pregnancy''' is the presence of [[HIV]] in a woman while she is [[Pregnancy|pregnant]]. HIV in pregnancy is of concern because women with [[HIV/AIDS]] may transmit the infection to their child during pregnancy, [[childbirth]] and while [[breastfeeding]]. However, the risk of [[Vertically transmitted infection|mother-to-child transmission]] of HIV may be reduced by treatment of the HIV infection with [[Management of HIV/AIDS|antiretroviral therapy]] (ART). This lifelong therapy may be initiated in women before, during, and after pregnancy. After delivery, children are also given the medication temporarily as a [[Post-exposure prophylaxis|prophylactic]] measure to reduce the risk of infection. Because HIV may also be spread through [[breast milk]], mothers in the United States who are infected are encouraged to avoid [[breastfeed]]ing.<ref name="aidsinfo2012">{{cite web | url = http://aidsinfo.nih.gov/contentfiles/perinatal_FS_en.pdf | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150421024106/http://aidsinfo.nih.gov/contentfiles/perinatal_FS_en.pdf | archive-date = 21 April 2015 | dead-url = yes | title = HIV and Pregnancy | website =aidsinfo.nih.gov | access-date = 1 August 2015 | publisher = U.S. Department of Health and Human Services | authors = (HHS) Panel on Treatment of HIV-Infected Pregnant Women and Prevention of Perinatal Transmission, a working group of the ''Office of AIDS Research Advisory Council'' (OARAC) }}</ref> However, in [[developing countries]] such as South Africa, where the risk of death of the infant associated with avoiding [[exclusive breastfeeding]] is higher than the risk of contracting HIV, exclusive breastfeeding in a mother who is virally suppressed is encouraged.<ref name=":9">{{cite book |url= http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/246260/9789241549707-eng.pdf?sequence=1 |title=Guideline: Updates on HIV and infant feeding|publisher=World Health Organisation, UNICEF|year=2016 }}</ref>
Infection with HIV/AIDS is not a [[contraindication]] to pregnancy. Women with the disease may choose to become pregnant if they desire, however, they are encouraged to talk with their doctors beforehand. Some women are unaware they have the disease until they become pregnant. In this case, they should begin antiretroviral therapy as soon as possible.<ref name="aidsinfo2012" /> With the appropriate treatment, the risk of [[HIV/AIDS#Mother-to-child|mother-to-child infection]] can be reduced to below 1%.<ref name="Mother2010">{{cite journal | vauthors = Coutsoudis A, Kwaan L, Thomson M | title = Prevention of vertical transmission of HIV-1 in resource-limited settings | journal = Expert Review of Anti-Infective Therapy | volume = 8 | issue = 10 | pages = 1163–75 | date = October 2010 | pmid = 20954881 | doi = 10.1586/eri.10.94 }}</ref> Without treatment, the risk of transmission is 15–45%.<ref>{{cite web|title = Mother-to-child transmission of HIV|url = http://www.who.int/hiv/topics/mtct/en/|website = World Health Organization|access-date = 2015-11-18|language = en-GB}}</ref>
There are approximately 1.4 million HIV positive women who become pregnant and contribute to more than 300,000 neonatal and fetal deaths each year.<ref>{{cite web | publisher = World Health Organization | year = 2013 | title = Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs) | url = http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/82207/1/WHO_RHR_13.02_eng.pdf }}</ref> With the use of ART, transmission of HIV from the mother to child has decreased according to reports by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO). In 2009, there were an estimated 400,000 children born with HIV and by 2013, there were 240,000.<ref>{{cite book |title = Children and Pregnant Women Living with HIV | publisher = UNAIDS |year = 2014 |isbn = 978-92-9253-062-4 | url = http://www.unaids.org/sites/default/files/media_asset/09_ChildrenandpregnantwomenlivingwithHIV.pdf }}</ref> Countries in [[Sub-Saharan Africa]] are worst affected by the HIV/AIDS pandemic. In 2010, 30% of all pregnancies in the region were affected by HIV. In 2011, HIV was responsible for 50% of the deaths of children below the age of five.<ref>{{cite web|title = WHO {{!}} Eliminating mother-to-child HIV transmission in South Africa|url = http://www.who.int/bulletin/volumes/91/1/12-106807/en/|website = www.who.int|access-date = 2015-11-20}}</ref> In the [[United States]], fewer than 200 babies are born with HIV every year.<ref name=aidsinfo2012/>
As of 2015, [[Cuba]] has become the first country in the world to eradicate mother-to-child transmission of HIV. In 2010, the WHO partnered with the [[Pan American Health Organization]] (PAHO) to implement an initiative that would provide early [[prenatal care]] and [[HIV Testing|HIV testing]] for all pregnant women in Cuba. For women who tested positive, ART was provided for both the mother and child, [[cesarean sections]] were performed, and alternatives to breastfeeding were provided. In implementing these measures, the country was successfully able to eradicate HIV transmission during pregnancy.<ref name=":3">{{cite web | url =http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2015/mtct-hiv-cuba/en/|title=WHO validates elimination of mother-to-child transmission of HIV and syphilis in Cuba|publisher=[[WHO]]| date=30 June 2015| access-date =30 Aug 2015}}</ref>
==Pregnancy planning== In couples where the male and female are both HIV positive, conception may occur normally without concern for disease transmission. However, in couples where only one partner is HIV positive there is risk of transmitting the infection to the uninfected partner. These couples, known as [[serodiscordant]] couples, are advised not to engage in unprotected intercourse. Instead, [[Assisted reproductive technology|assistive reproductive method]]s are recommended.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal | vauthors = van Leeuwen E, Prins JM, Jurriaans S, Boer K, Reiss P, Repping S, van der Veen F | title = Reproduction and fertility in human immunodeficiency virus type-1 infection | journal = Human Reproduction Update | volume = 13 | issue = 2 | pages = 197–206 | date = 2007-03-01 | pmid = 17099206 | doi = 10.1093/humupd/dml052 }}</ref> In all serodiscordant couples, the infected partner is advised to begin ART so that their [[Viral load monitoring for HIV|viral load]] is undetectable prior to attempting conception.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cohen MS, Chen YQ, McCauley M, Gamble T, Hosseinipour MC, Kumarasamy N, Hakim JG, Kumwenda J, Grinsztejn B, Pilotto JH, Godbole SV, Mehendale S, Chariyalertsak S, Santos BR, Mayer KH, Hoffman IF, Eshleman SH, Piwowar-Manning E, Wang L, Makhema J, Mills LA, de Bruyn G, Sanne I, Eron J, Gallant J, Havlir D, Swindells S, Ribaudo H, Elharrar V, Burns D, Taha TE, Nielsen-Saines K, Celentano D, Essex M, Fleming TR | display-authors = 6 | title = Prevention of HIV-1 infection with early antiretroviral therapy | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 365 | issue = 6 | pages = 493–505 | date = August 2011 | pmid = 21767103 | pmc = 3200068 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMoa1105243 }}</ref>
In couples where the woman is HIV negative and the man is HIV positive, sperm is collected from the male partner and HIV is removed from the specimen using a technique called [[sperm washing]]. This process is then followed by [[intrauterine insemination]] (IUI) or [[in vitro fertilization]] (IVF). Couples may also use donor sperm from a non-infected male if desired.<ref name="Savasi2013">{{cite journal | vauthors = Savasi V, Mandia L, Laoreti A, Cetin I | title = Reproductive assistance in HIV serodiscordant couples | journal = Human Reproduction Update | volume = 19 | issue = 2 | pages = 136–50 | year = 2012 | pmid = 23146867 | pmc = | doi = 10.1093/humupd/dms046 }}</ref>
In couples where the woman is HIV positive and the man is HIV negative, [[artificial insemination]] is recommended.<ref name="Savasi2013" />
In areas where assistive reproductive techniques, such as IUI or IVF, are not available, techniques used during intercourse can be attempted to reduce, but not eliminate, the risk of HIV transmission.<ref name = "lvguidelines" /> Most importantly, the [[HPTN 052]] trial showed that when HIV infected partners were on ART and their viral load was undetectable no transmission occurred; in partners with a detectable viral load on ART there was 96% less transmission.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cohen MS, Chen YQ, McCauley M, Gamble T, Hosseinipour MC, Kumarasamy N, Hakim JG, Kumwenda J, Grinsztejn B, Pilotto JH, Godbole SV, Mehendale S, Chariyalertsak S, Santos BR, Mayer KH, Hoffman IF, Eshleman SH, Piwowar-Manning E, Wang L, Makhema J, Mills LA, de Bruyn G, Sanne I, Eron J, Gallant J, Havlir D, Swindells S, Ribaudo H, Elharrar V, Burns D, Taha TE, Nielsen-Saines K, Celentano D, Essex M, Fleming TR | display-authors = 6 | title = Prevention of HIV-1 infection with early antiretroviral therapy | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 365 | issue = 6 | pages = 493–505 | date = August 2011 | pmid = 21767103 | pmc = 3200068 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMoa1105243 | url = http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:HUL.InstRepos:26667502 }}</ref>
Many serodiscordant couples use [[pre-exposure prophylaxis]] (PrEP) to limit transmission of the infection to the uninfected partner. Daily use of PrEP has been shown to decrease transmission of the infection by an average of 63–75%. However, use of PrEP during pregnancy has not yet been studied and its long-term effects on the foetus are unknown.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Thigpen MC, Kebaabetswe PM, Paxton LA, Smith DK, Rose CE, Segolodi TM, Henderson FL, Pathak SR, Soud FA, Chillag KL, Mutanhaurwa R, Chirwa LI, Kasonde M, Abebe D, Buliva E, Gvetadze RJ, Johnson S, Sukalac T, Thomas VT, Hart C, Johnson JA, Malotte CK, Hendrix CW, Brooks JT | display-authors = 6 | title = Antiretroviral preexposure prophylaxis for heterosexual HIV transmission in Botswana | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 367 | issue = 5 | pages = 423–34 | date = August 2012 | pmid = 22784038 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMoa1110711 }}</ref>
Although assisted reproductive techniques are available for serodiscordant couples, there are still limitations to achieving a successful pregnancy. Women with HIV have been shown to have decreased fertility, which can affect the available reproductive options.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Glynn JR, Buvé A, Caraël M, Kahindo M, Macauley IB, Musonda RM, Jungmann E, Tembo F, Zekeng L | title = Decreased fertility among HIV-1-infected women attending antenatal clinics in three African cities | journal = Journal of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndromes | volume = 25 | issue = 4 | pages = 345–52 | date = December 2000 | pmid = 11114835 | doi = 10.1097/00126334-200012010-00008 }}</ref> Women with HIV are also more likely to be infected with other sexually transmitted diseases, placing them at higher risk for infertility. Males with HIV appear to have decreased semen volume and sperm motility, which decreases their fertility.<ref name=":0" /> ART may also affect both male and female fertility and some drugs can be [[Teratogen|toxic]] to embryos.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kushnir VA, Lewis W | title = Human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome and infertility: emerging problems in the era of highly active antiretrovirals | journal = Fertility and Sterility | volume = 96 | issue = 3 | pages = 546–53 | date = September 2011 | pmid = 21722892 | pmc = 3165097 | doi = 10.1016/j.fertnstert.2011.05.094 }}</ref> Additionally, there have been cases where an HIV-negative partner was infected with the disease despite artificial insemination with washed sperm.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = | title = HIV-1 infection and artificial insemination with processed semen | journal = MMWR. Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report | volume = 39 | issue = 15 | pages = 249, 255–6 | date = April 1990 | pmid = 2109169 }}</ref>
==HIV testing in pregnancy== {{Further|Diagnosis of HIV/AIDS}} The [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention]] (CDC) recommends [[Diagnosis of HIV/AIDS|HIV testing]] for all pregnant women as a part of routine prenatal care. The test is usually performed in the first trimester of pregnancy with other routine laboratory tests. HIV testing is recommended because HIV-infected women who do not receive testing are more likely to transmit the infection to their children.<ref name=":1">{{cite web|title = Opt-Out{{!}} Pregnant Women, Infants, and Children {{!}} Gender {{!}} HIV by Group {{!}} HIV/AIDS {{!}} CDC|url = https://www.cdc.gov/hiv/group/gender/pregnantwomen/opt-out.html|website = www.cdc.gov|access-date = 2015-11-13}}</ref>
HIV testing may be offered to pregnant women on an ''opt-in'' or an ''opt-out'' basis. In the ''opt-in'' model, women are counseled on HIV testing and elect to receive the test by signing a consent form. In the ''opt-out'' model, the HIV test is automatically performed with other routine prenatal tests. If a woman does not want to be tested for HIV, she must specifically refuse the test and sign a form declining testing. The CDC recommends ''opt-out'' testing for all pregnant women because it improves disease detection and treatment and helps reduce transmission to children.<ref name=":1" />
If a woman chooses to decline testing, she will not receive the test. However, she will continue to receive HIV counseling throughout the pregnancy so that she may be as informed as possible about the disease and its impact. She will be offered HIV testing at all stages of her pregnancy in case she changes her mind.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://aidsinfo.nih.gov/contentfiles/hivtestingandpregnancy_fs_en.pdf | access-date = 1 February 2012 | publisher = U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) | title = Recommendations for Use of Antiretroviral Drugs in Pregnant HIV-1-Infected Women for Maternal Health and Interventions to Reduce Perinatal HIV Transmission in the United States. }}</ref>
HIV testing begins with a [[Screening (medicine)|screening test]]. The most common screening test is the [[Diagnosis of HIV/AIDS|rapid HIV antibody test]] which tests for HIV [[Antibody|antibodies]] in blood, urine, or oral fluid. HIV antibodies are only produced if an individual is infected with the disease. Therefore, presence of the antibodies is indicative of an HIV infection. Sometimes, however, a person may be infected with HIV but the body has not produced enough antibodies to be detected by the test. If a woman has risk factors for HIV infection but tests negative on the initial screening test, she should be retested in 3 months to confirm that she does not have HIV.<ref name=":2">{{cite journal | vauthors = Cornett JK, Kirn TJ | title = Laboratory diagnosis of HIV in adults: a review of current methods | journal = Clinical Infectious Diseases | volume = 57 | issue = 5 | pages = 712–8 | date = September 2013 | pmid = 23667267 | doi = 10.1093/cid/cit281 }}</ref> Another screening test that is more specific is the [[Diagnosis of HIV/AIDS|HIV antigen/antibody test]]. This is a newer blood test that can detect HIV infection quicker than the antibody test because it detects both virus particles and antibodies in the blood.<ref name="pmid23911678">{{cite journal | vauthors = Masciotra S, Luo W, Youngpairoj AS, Kennedy MS, Wells S, Ambrose K, Sprinkle P, Owen SM | display-authors = 6 | title = Performance of the Alere Determine™ HIV-1/2 Ag/Ab Combo Rapid Test with specimens from HIV-1 seroconverters from the US and HIV-2 infected individuals from Ivory Coast | journal = Journal of Clinical Virology : the Official Publication of the Pan American Society for Clinical Virology | volume = 58 | issue = Suppl 1 | pages = e54–8 | date = December 2013 | pmid = 23911678 | doi = 10.1016/j.jcv.2013.07.002 }}</ref>
Any woman who has a positive HIV screening test must receive follow-up testing to confirm the diagnosis. The follow-up test can differentiate HIV-1 from HIV-2 and is a more specific antibody test. It may also detect the virus directly in the bloodstream.<ref name=":2" />
==Prevention of mother-to-child transmission== HIV/AIDS may be [[Vertically transmitted infection|vertically transmitted]] from a mother to her child. This means the infection may be spread during pregnancy, [[Childbirth|labor]], delivery, or breastfeeding. 70% of transmissions are believed to occur during delivery when the baby comes into direct contact with the mother's infected blood or genital secretions/fluid in the birth canal. 30% of infections occur [[in utero]] during the pregnancy with 66% occurring within the last 14 days of a pregnancy.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Minkoff H | title = Human immunodeficiency virus infection in pregnancy | journal = Obstetrics and Gynecology | volume = 101 | issue = 4 | pages = 797–810 | date = April 2003 | pmid = 12681888 | doi = 10.1097/00006250-200304000-00038 }}</ref> The mechanism for in utero infection is not well understood, but the current belief is that infected maternal secretions may cross the placenta during the pregnancy.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lee TH, Chafets DM, Biggar RJ, McCune JM, Busch MP | title = The role of transplacental microtransfusions of maternal lymphocytes in in utero HIV transmission | journal = Journal of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndromes | volume = 55 | issue = 2 | pages = 143–7 | date = October 2010 | pmid = 20683195 | pmc = 3509795 | doi = 10.1097/QAI.0b013e3181eb301e }}</ref>
The risk of HIV transmission from a mother to child is most directly related to the plasma [[viral load]] of the mother. Untreated mothers with a viral load >100,000 copies/ml have a transmission risk of over 50%.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Garcia PM, Kalish LA, Pitt J, Minkoff H, Quinn TC, Burchett SK, Kornegay J, Jackson B, Moye J, Hanson C, Zorrilla C, Lew JF | display-authors = 6 | title = Maternal levels of plasma human immunodeficiency virus type 1 RNA and the risk of perinatal transmission. Women and Infants Transmission Study Group | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 341 | issue = 6 | pages = 394–402 | date = August 1999 | pmid = 10432324 | doi = 10.1056/NEJM199908053410602 }}</ref> For women with a viral load <1000 copies/ml, the risk of transmission is less than 1%.<ref>{{cite journal | author = European Collaborative Study | title = Mother-to-child transmission of HIV infection in the era of highly active antiretroviral therapy | journal = Clinical Infectious Diseases | volume = 40 | issue = 3 | pages = 458–65 | date = February 2005 | pmid = 15668871 | doi = 10.1086/427287 }}</ref> In general, the lower the viral load the lower the risk of transmission. For this reason, ART is recommended throughout the pregnancy so that viral load levels remain as low as possible and the risk of transmission is reduced.
Women with an established diagnosis of HIV often begin ART before becoming pregnant to treat the infection. It is recommended that all pregnant women begin ART regardless of CD4 counts or viral load to reduce the risk of transmission. The earlier ART is initiated, the more likely the viral load will be suppressed by the time of delivery.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Townsend CL, Byrne L, Cortina-Borja M, Thorne C, de Ruiter A, Lyall H, Taylor GP, Peckham CS, Tookey PA | display-authors = 6 | title = Earlier initiation of ART and further decline in mother-to-child HIV transmission rates, 2000-2011 | journal = AIDS | volume = 28 | issue = 7 | pages = 1049–57 | date = April 2014 | pmid = 24566097 | doi = 10.1097/QAD.0000000000000212 }}</ref> Some women are concerned about using ART early in the pregnancy, as babies are most susceptible to drug toxicities during the first trimester. However, delay in ART initiation may prove less effective in reducing infection transmission.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hoffman RM, Black V, Technau K, van der Merwe KJ, Currier J, Coovadia A, Chersich M | title = Effects of highly active antiretroviral therapy duration and regimen on risk for mother-to-child transmission of HIV in Johannesburg, South Africa | journal = Journal of Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndromes | volume = 54 | issue = 1 | pages = 35–41 | date = May 2010 | pmid = 20216425 | pmc = 2880466 | doi = 10.1097/QAI.0b013e3181cf9979 }}</ref>
Antiretroviral therapy is used at the following times in pregnancy to reduce the risk of mother-to-child transmission of HIV:<ref name="aidsinfo2012" /> * During pregnancy: pregnant women infected with HIV receive an oral regimen of at least three different anti-HIV medications (such as [[Tenofovir disoproxil|tenofovir]], [[emtricitabine]] and [[efavirenz]]). * During labor and delivery: pregnant women infected with HIV and already on triple ART are recommended to continue with their oral regimen. If their viral load is >1,000 copies/ml or there is question about whether medications have been taken consistently, then [[Intravenous therapy|intravenous]] [[zidovudine]] (AZT) is added at the time of delivery.<ref name = "lvguidelines" /> Pregnant women who have not been on ART prior to delivery or who have been on ART for less than four weeks should also be given intravenous AZT or a single dose of [[nifedipine]] (NVD), tenofovir (TDF) and emtricitabine (FTC) and a three-hourly dose of AZT.<ref name=":10" />
===Indications to start medications=== According to current recommendations by the WHO, US CDC and U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (DHHS), all individuals with HIV should begin ART. The recommendation is stronger under the following conditions:<ref name=":4">{{cite web|title = When to Start Antiretroviral Therapy {{!}} HIV/AIDS Fact Sheets {{!}} Education Materials {{!}} AIDSinfo|url = https://aidsinfo.nih.gov/education-materials/fact-sheets/21/52/when-to-start-antiretroviral-therapy|website = AIDSinfo|access-date = 2015-11-21}}</ref> * [[CD4 count]] below 350 cells/mm<sup>3</sup> * High viral load (>100,000 copies/ml) * Progression of HIV to AIDS * Development of HIV-related infections and illnesses * Pregnancy Women are encouraged to begin treatment as soon as they are diagnosed with HIV. If they are diagnosed prior to pregnancy, they should continue with ART during the pregnancy. If the diagnosis of HIV is made during the pregnancy, ART should be initiated immediately.<ref name=":4" />
===Medications during pregnancy=== The goal of antiretroviral use during pregnancy is to reduce the risk of transmission of HIV from mother to child. It is important to choose medications that are safe for the mother and the fetus and which are effective at decreasing the total viral load. Some studies have shown an increase in stillbirths, preterm delivery, and delayed fetal growth in women using high doses of antiretroviral drugs during pregnancy. However, the overall benefits of ART are believed to outweigh the risks and all women are encouraged to use ART for the duration of their pregnancy.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Chen JY, Ribaudo HJ, Souda S, Parekh N, Ogwu A, Lockman S, Powis K, Dryden-Peterson S, Creek T, Jimbo W, Madidimalo T, Makhema J, Essex M, Shapiro RL | display-authors = 6 | title = Highly active antiretroviral therapy and adverse birth outcomes among HIV-infected women in Botswana | journal = The Journal of Infectious Diseases | volume = 206 | issue = 11 | pages = 1695–705 | date = December 2012 | pmid = 23066160 | pmc = 3488194 | doi = 10.1093/infdis/jis553 }}</ref>
Due to physiological changes in the body during pregnancy, it may be necessary to alter the dosing of medications so that they remain effective. Generally, the dose or the frequency of dosing are increased to account for these changes.
The recommended ART regimen for HIV-positive pregnant women consists of drugs from 4 different classes of medications listed below. In the United States, the favored regimen is a three-drug regimen where the first two drugs are NRTIs and the third is either a protease inhibitor, an integrase inhibitor, or an NNRTI.<ref name="lvguidelines">{{cite web | author = Panel on Treatment of HIV-Infected Pregnant Women and Prevention of Perinatal Transmission. | title = Recommendations for Use of Antiretroviral Drugs in Pregnant HIV-1-Infected Women for Maternal Health and Interventions to Reduce Perinatal HIV Transmission in the United States | url = http://aidsinfo.nih.gov/contentfiles/lvguidelines/PerinatalGL.pdf | access-date = 20 November 2015 }}</ref>
*[[Nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor]]s (NRTIs) are considered the "backbone" of ART and 2 medications are generally used in combination. Due to its known safety profile and extensive use in pregnant patients, [[zidovudine]]-[[lamivudine]] (ZDV/3TC) is the preferred choice as the NRTI backbone. Zidovudine may worsen anemia, so patients with anemia are advised to use an alternative agent. For women who are coinfected with [[hepatitis B]], [[tenofovir]] (TDF) with either [[emtricitabine]] (FTC) or lamivudine is the preferred NRTI backbone.<ref name="lvguidelines" /> NRTI use may cause [[lactic acidosis]] in some women, so it is important to monitor patients for this complication. Deaths from lactic acidosis and liver failure have been associated with the use of two NRTIs, [[stavudine]] and [[didanosine]] (d4t and ddl, respectively); therefore, combinations involving these drugs should be avoided in pregnancy.<ref name="aidsinfo2012" /> *[[Protease inhibitor (pharmacology)|Protease inhibitor]]s (PIs) have been studied extensively in pregnancy and are therefore the preferred third drug in the regimen. [[Atazanavir]]-[[ritonavir]] (ATV/r) and [[darunavir]]-ritonavir (DRV/r) are two of the most common PIs used during pregnancy. There is conflicting data regarding their association with preterm births, so women who are at a high risk for premature delivery are advised not to use PIs.<ref name="lvguidelines" /> Some PIs have been associated with [[hyperglycemia]] but is unclear whether they add to the risk of developing [[gestational diabetes]].<ref name="aidsinfo2012" /> Some PIs have been noted to cause [[hyperbilirubinemia]] and nausea, so these side effects should be monitored for closely. *[[Integrase inhibitor]]s (IIs) are generally the third drug in the regimen when a PI cannot be used. They rapidly reduce the viral load and for this reason, they are often used in women who are diagnosed with HIV late in their pregnancy. [[Raltegravir]] (RAL) is the most common used. *[[Non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor]]s (NNRTIs), the most popular being [[efavirenz]] (EFV) and [[nevirapine]] (NVP), may be used during pregnancy. However, there are significant toxicities associated with their use, making them a less desirable option. **[[Efavirenz]] ([[brand name]] Sustiva, shortened as EFV, and a component of the combination drug [[Atripla]]) is classified as a [[Pregnancy category|category D]] drug by the US [[Food and Drug Administration]] indicating there are risks associated with its use during pregnancy. In a study analyzing the use of the drug in pregnant women, 2.3% of births were associated with birth defects.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.accessdata.fda.gov/drugsatfda_docs/label/2010/021360s024lbl.pdf|title = HIGHLIGHTS OF PRESCRIBING INFORMATION|access-date = 2014-04-11}}</ref> However, a systematic review of the safety of EFV use in humans during the first trimester found no increase in birth defects among women using the drug.<ref name=":6">{{cite journal | vauthors = Ford N, Calmy A, Mofenson L | title = Safety of efavirenz in the first trimester of pregnancy: an updated systematic review and meta-analysis | journal = AIDS | volume = 25 | issue = 18 | pages = 2301–4 | date = November 2011 | pmid = 21918421 | doi = 10.1097/QAD.0b013e32834cdb71 }}</ref> Given the uncertain potential for risk, the U.S. DHHS recommends against using EFV in the first trimester of pregnancy or in women who may become pregnant. They instead recommend a protease inhibitor based regimen with [[lopinavir]] (LPV) or ATV.<ref name="lvguidelines" /> However, to simplify regimens and provide a uniform recommendation for HIV-infected individuals during pregnancy, the WHO continues to recommend efavirenz as a first line agent for HIV positive women.<ref name="who2013">{{cite web|url = http://www.who.int/hiv/pub/guidelines/arv2013/download/en/|title = WHO {{!}} Consolidated guidelines on the use of antiretroviral drugs for treating and preventing HIV infection |date = June 30, 2013|isbn = 978 92 4 150572 7|pages = 38}}</ref> Women using EFV prior to their pregnancy may continue with the drug as it is more dangerous to stop or change medications during pregnancy because this can result in improper control of the viral load.<ref name=":6" /> **[[Nevirapine]] ([[trade name]] Viramune, and shortened NVP) increases the risk of very serious liver damage in women with CD4 counts greater than 250 cells/mm<sup>3</sup> . It is generally avoided in pregnant women. Women taking NVP safely prior to pregnancy may continue with the medication because NVP-related liver damage has not been seen in women previously using the medication.<ref name="aidsinfo2012" />
===Nutritional supplements=== [[Vitamin A]] plays a role in the [[immune system]] and is a low-cost intervention that has been suggested to help with preventing mother-to-child transmission of HIV. A Cochrane review<ref>Wiysonge CS, Ndze VN, Kongnyuy EJ, Shey MS. Vitamin A supplements for reducing mother-to-child HIV transmission. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews 2017, Issue 9. Art. No.: CD003648. DOI: 10.1002/14651858.CD003648.pub4.</ref> summarised the evidence of five trials conducted in Malawi, South Africa, Tanzania and Zimbabwe between 1995 and 2005, where none of the participants received [[antiretroviral therapy]]. They found that giving vitamin A supplementation to pregnant women or to women after they delivered a baby probably has little or no effect on mother-to-child transmission of HIV. The intervention has been largely superseded by antiretroviral therapy.
===Labor and delivery=== Women should continue their ART regimen through childbirth.
The viral load helps determine which mode of delivery is safest for the mother and the baby. In cases where the viral load is low (<1000 copies/mL), the risk of transmission is low and a vaginal delivery may be performed. A cesarean section, on the other hand, is generally performed at 38 weeks gestation under the following circumstances:<ref name=":8">{{cite web|title = HIV and pregnancy|url = http://www.uptodate.com/contents/hiv-and-pregnancy-beyond-the-basics|website = www.uptodate.com|access-date = 2015-11-21}}</ref> * Viral load is high (>1000 copies/mL) or unknown at the time of delivery * Mother did not receive ART during the pregnancy * Mother is concerned about exposing her child to infected blood and genital secretions during the delivery If, before her scheduled cesarean section, a woman's [[rupture of membranes|water breaks]] and she goes into labor, a cesarean section may not significantly reduce the risk of infection transmission. Under this circumstance, if there is no other medical reason to proceed with a cesarean section, a vaginal delivery may be performed and may be the safest for the mother and the baby.<ref name=aidsinfo2012/>
Women who present to the hospital in labor with an unknown HIV status should undergo immediate HIV testing. If the initial screening test is positive, the mother should immediately be given a single dose of nifedipine (NVD), tenofovir (TDF) and emtricitabine (FTC) and a three-hourly dose of zidovudine (AZT) and the baby should receive prophylactic ART after birth. This will help reduce the risk of HIV transmission during labor and delivery. A confirmatory HIV test should also be performed in the meantime. If the test results are positive, treatment should continue. If the results are negative, the medications may be stopped.<ref name=":10" /><ref name=":8" />
=== Breastfeeding === Women may transmit HIV to their child via [[Breast milk|breastmilk]]. For this reason, [[breastfeeding]] is discouraged in the United States amongst HIV-positive women.<ref name="aidsinfo2012" /> However, in [[developing countries]] such as [[South Africa]], where the risk of death of the infant associated with avoiding [[exclusive breastfeeding]] is higher than the risk of contracting HIV, exclusive breastfeeding in a mother who is virally suppressed is encouraged.<ref name=":9" />
In [[developed countries]], where clean water and infant formula are both accessible and available, HIV-positive women should not breastfeed. They should use formula to reduce the risk of transmitting HIV to the child. Even if the mother is on ART, she should avoid breastfeeding as HIV can still be transmitted through the breastmilk. Some women elect to use [[Human milk banking in North America|donor milk]] (breast milk donated from non-HIV infected mothers) instead of formula so that their child may receive the health benefits of breast milk, the most notable being increased immunity.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hoddinott P, Tappin D, Wright C | title = Breast feeding | journal = BMJ | volume = 336 | issue = 7649 | pages = 881–7 | date = April 2008 | pmid = 18420694 | pmc = 2323059 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.39521.566296.BE | hdl = 1893/10055 }}</ref>
In underdeveloped countries, where clean water and formula are not as readily available, breastfeeding is encouraged to provide the child with adequate food and nutrients. The benefit of nourishment outweighs the risk of HIV transmission so breastfeeding is acceptable.<ref name="who2013" /> The [[South African Department of Health]] guidelines state that HIV-infected mothers should exclusively breastfeed, that is the infant's diet should consist of breastmilk only and should not be supplemented with water, other liquids or foods, for 6 months after birth. After 6 months, the mother should introduce complementary foods while continuing to breastfeed for up to 24 months.<ref name=":10">{{cite book | url = http://www.sahivsoc.org/Files/ART%20Guidelines%2015052015.pdf | title=National Consolidated Guidelines for the prevention of mother-to-child transmission of HIV (PMTCT) and the management of HIV in children, adolescents and adults |publisher=National Department of Health, South Africa|year=|isbn=|location=|publication-date=April 2015 }}</ref><ref name=":9" /><sup>:7</sup>
In a study conducted in South Africa, 1.1% of children born to HIV-infected mothers who were uninfected at 6 weeks of age, were infected within 1 month of breastfeeding and 4.0% were infected by 6 months of age.<ref name="pmid17398310">{{cite journal | vauthors = Coovadia HM, Rollins NC, Bland RM, Little K, Coutsoudis A, Bennish ML, Newell ML | display-authors = 6 | title = Mother-to-child transmission of HIV-1 infection during exclusive breastfeeding in the first 6 months of life: an intervention cohort study | journal = Lancet | volume = 369 | issue = 9567 | pages = 1107–16 | date = March 2007 | pmid = 17398310 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(07)60283-9 }}</ref> A study in Malawi found that the risk of HIV transmission through breastfeeding was 7% in children who breastfed for one year and 10% in children who breastfed for two years. The risk of HIV infection appears to be highest in the early months of breastfeeding and HIV-infected mothers who are not virally suppressed should avoid breastfeeding entirely if possible.<ref name="pmid10463709">{{cite journal | vauthors = Miotti PG, Taha TE, Kumwenda NI, Broadhead R, Mtimavalye LA, Van der Hoeven L, Chiphangwi JD, Liomba G, Biggar RJ | display-authors = 6 | title = HIV transmission through breastfeeding: a study in Malawi | journal = Jama | volume = 282 | issue = 8 | pages = 744–9 | date = August 1999 | pmid = 10463709 | doi = 10.1001/jama.282.8.744 }}</ref> In contrast, a systematic review commissioned by the WHO found that there is a very low risk (1.1%) of postnatal HIV transmission in infants breastfed by mothers on lifelong ART that was initiated in early to mid pregnancy. The overall risk of transmission was 3.3%, including exposures ''in utero'' and during childbirth.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Bispo S, Chikhungu L, Rollins N, Siegfried N, Newell ML | title = Postnatal HIV transmission in breastfed infants of HIV-infected women on ART: a systematic review and meta-analysis | journal = Journal of the International AIDS Society | volume = 20 | issue = 1 | pages = 21251 | date = February 2017 | pmid = 28362072 | pmc = 5467610 | doi = 10.7448/IAS.20.1.21251 }}</ref> Another systematic review found that prolonged breastfeeding for infants born to mothers on lifelong ART is beneficial in terms of HIV‐free survival at least up to 24 months of age – increasing HIV-free survival rates from 89% to 96%.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Chikhungu LC, Bispo S, Rollins N, Siegfried N, Newell ML | title = HIV-free survival at 12-24 months in breastfed infants of HIV-infected women on antiretroviral treatment | journal = Tropical Medicine & International Health | volume = 21 | issue = 7 | pages = 820–8 | date = July 2016 | pmid = 27120500 | pmc = 5096069 | doi = 10.1111/tmi.12710 }}</ref>
If the mother has a high HIV [[viral load]] (>1000 copies/L), replacement feeding, such as formula, is only initiated as per the [[UNAIDS]] guidelines, termed the AFASS criteria, "where replacement feeding is acceptable, feasible, affordable, sustainable, and safe."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.unicef.org/programme/breastfeeding/feeding.htm|title=WHO/UNAIDS/UNICEF infant feeding guidelines|last=|first=|date=|website=www.unicef.org|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-06}}</ref><ref name=":10" /><sup>:95-6</sup> A mother may only be given infant formula, as explained by the WHO, if the following conditions are met:<ref name=":9" />
* "Safe water and sanitation are assured at the household level and in the community; and * the mother or other caregiver can reliably provide sufficient infant formula milk to support the normal growth and development of the infant; and * the mother or caregiver can prepare it cleanly and frequently enough so that it is safe and carries a low risk of diarrhoea and malnutrition; and * the mother or caregiver can exclusively give infant formula milk in the first six months; and * the family is supportive of this practice; and * the mother or caregiver can access health care that offers comprehensive child health services."
==Other considerations during pregnancy== Pregnant women with HIV may still receive the trivalent inactivated [[influenza vaccine]] and the tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis (Tdap) vaccination during pregnancy.<ref name="MadhiCutland2014">{{cite journal | vauthors = Madhi SA, Cutland CL, Kuwanda L, Weinberg A, Hugo A, Jones S, Adrian PV, van Niekerk N, Treurnicht F, Ortiz JR, Venter M, Violari A, Neuzil KM, Simões EA, Klugman KP, Nunes MC | display-authors = 6 | title = Influenza vaccination of pregnant women and protection of their infants | journal = The New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 371 | issue = 10 | pages = 918–31 | date = September 2014 | pmid = 25184864 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMoa1401480 | hdl = 2263/42412 }}</ref>
Many patients who are HIV positive also have other health conditions known as [[Comorbidity|comorbidities]]. Hepatitis B, hepatitis C, tuberculosis and injection drug use are some of the most common comorbidities associated with HIV. Women who screen positive for HIV should also be tested for these conditions so that they may be adequately treated or controlled during the pregnancy. The comorbidities may have serious adverse effects on the mother and child during pregnancy, so it is extremely important to identify them early during the pregnancy.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Solomon SS, Hawcroft CS, Narasimhan P, Subbaraman R, Srikrishnan AK, Cecelia AJ, Suresh Kumar M, Solomon S, Gallant JE, Celentano DD | display-authors = 6 | title = Comorbidities among HIV-infected injection drug users in Chennai, India | journal = The Indian Journal of Medical Research | volume = 127 | issue = 5 | pages = 447–52 | date = May 2008 | pmid = 18653907 }}</ref>
==Postnatal care== Babies born to HIV-positive women should receive a 6-week or 12-week course of zidovudine (AZT). The medication should ideally be started within the first 6 to 12 hours of life, but can be started up to 72 hours after birth.<ref name=":10" /> A 6-week course should be initiated if the mother has been on ART for more than four weeks before birth, and a 12-week course should be initiated if the mother is newly diagnosed or has been on ART for less than four weeks before birth.<ref name=":10" /> The baby should be tested for HIV at birth, 4 weeks after cessation of AZT (10 weeks or 16 weeks, depending on length of AZT course, after birth), 6 weeks after cessation of breastfeeding and at 18 months.<ref name=":10" /> Usual antibody based testing is unreliable in infants until the age of 18 months due to the transmission of [[maternal antibodies]]. A qualitative HIV [[DNA]] [[Polymerase chain reaction|PCR]] assay is recommended as it will detect pro-viral HIV DNA since HIV RNA may be suppressed by ART.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Read JS | title = Diagnosis of HIV-1 infection in children younger than 18 months in the United States | journal = Pediatrics | volume = 120 | issue = 6 | pages = e1547-62 | date = December 2007 | pmid = 18055670 | doi = 10.1542/peds.2007-2951 }}</ref> In order to ensure the baby is HIV-negative, there must be two negative test results. Since zidovudine has been known to cause or worsen anemia, the baby's blood count should be routinely checked during AZT therapy.<ref>{{cite web | title = Recommendations for Use of Antiretroviral Drugs in Pregnant HIV-1-Infected Women for Maternal Health and Interventions to Reduce Perinatal HIV Transmission in the United States. | url = http://aidsinfo.nih.gov/guidelines | access-date = 21 November 2015 }}</ref>
To reduce the risk of developing ''[[Pneumocystis pneumonia|Pneumocystis jirovecii]]'' [[Pneumocystis pneumonia|pneumonia]] (PJP), all infants born to HIV-positive mothers should receive [[trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole]] (cotrimoxazole) from 4–6 weeks after birth, and stop prophylaxis when they are no longer at risk of contracting HIV from their mother.<ref name=":10" />
Although the risk is very low, HIV can also be transmitted to a baby through food that was previously chewed (pre-chewed) by a mother or caretaker infected with HIV. To be safe, babies should not be fed pre-chewed food.<ref name=aidsinfo2012/>
